tgt_text.7: APOLLONIUS'S USE OF POSSESSIVE ADJECTIVES AND PER­ SONAL PRONOUNS ....... xxivVII.
tgt_text.8: TRANSLATION OF THE POEM WITH NOTES ... 1A POLLONIUS RHODIUS was born about B.C. 235, in the reign of Ptolemy Euergetes, either at Alexandria or at Naucratis.
tgt_text.9: Strabo is in favour of the former, while Athenæus and Ælian declare for the latter place.
tgt_text.10: He appears to have given himself up at an early age to literary pursuits, and his choice is scarcely to be wondered at when we reflect upon the age in which he lived and the literary atmosphere in which he found himself.
tgt_text.11: We are not expressly told whether it was choice or necessity that led him to select the career he did, but from the fact that the leading poet of that day took the young aspirant in hand and instructed him in his art, we may fairly infer that Apollonius was a man of some standing and position in life.
tgt_text.12: His studies, however, under his master Callimachus were not destined to do either pupil or teacher.
tgt_text.14: no doubt he obtained some technical skill in his art, but the tastes of Callimachus and Apollonius were so diametrically opposed that the two poets quarrelled, and allowed their professional jealousy to go to such lengths that Apollonius lampooned the style of his teacher, while Callimachus was weak enough to retaliate in a studied retort under the title of " Ibis," the character of which poem, though lost to us, may be gathered from Ovid's poem of the same name.
tgt_text.15: Callimachus was the leading exponent of the strained and artificial poetry of his day.
tgt_text.16: Apollonius, with more true artistic instinct, revolted from the want of reality characteristic of most of his contemporaries, and having a genuine admiration for the straightforward simplicity of the Epic age, set himself to imitate Homer.
tgt_text.17: Naturally he made many enemies among the host of poetasters who took their cue from the animosity shown to him by the " Laureate " of the Alexandrine court.
tgt_text.18: Hence, when the “ Argonautica" appeared, it was at once condemned as violating the accepted canons of style and composition, and partly, perhaps, owing to certain youthful crudities which were afterwards corrected.
tgt_text.19: Great was the chagrin of the young poet at the reception of his work, and fierce was his anger against Callimachus.
tgt_text.20: The position of the latter, however, was unassailable, and so Apollonius, after a fruitless wordy warfare, determined to seek some new opening for his genius.
tgt_text.21: Accordingly he bade farewell to ungrateful Alexandria, and retired to Rhodes, then the second great seat of literature, taking his poem with him.
tgt_text.22: Possibly experience had taught him wherein his poem was deficient.
tgt_text.23: At any rate, he revised the whole of it;
tgt_text.24: and now, free from the cabals of jealous rivals, he received a fair verdict, and at once rose to fame.
tgt_text.25: So popular, indeed, did he become on the reading of his poem, that the Rhodians, it is said, rewarded him with extraordinary honours, and conferred their franchise upon him.
tgt_text.26: From this incident in his career he came to be called “the Rhodian," a name which has clung to him for ever.
tgt_text.27: It was only natural that in his hour of triumph he should long to have his merit acknowledged in his native city-in Alexandria, the gathering place of the old world's declining literature and art.
tgt_text.28: Thither, therefore, he came, with his honours upon him, and whether it was that Callimachus and his followers were out of favour, or whether the Alexandrines had relented towards their ill­ used poet, certain it is that he attained to great celebrity, and was advanced to valuable posts of trust.
tgt_text.29: Henceforth he could afford to rest upon his hardly-won laurels, his period of " Sturm und Drang " was over ;
tgt_text.30: he had passed through the fire, and it had done him no hurt—weighed in the balance he had not been found wanting.
tgt_text.31: Of his life henceforth we learn but little, beyond what Suidas tells us as to his having become librarian in the vast royal museum at Alexandria, about B.C. 194.
tgt_text.32: It may well be that this was so;
tgt_text.33: for the Ptolemies, in whose reigns Apollonius lived and wrote, were monarchs not unlikely to bestow such an important literary post upon a man of marked ability and studious habits.
tgt_text.34: Assuming that Suidas is correct in his statement, we find plenty of internal evidence in the poem to suggest that the writer must have been a man of vast erudition, or have had at his command extensive stores of knowledge from which to draw his materials.
tgt_text.35: During this period of his life the poet was not idle.
tgt_text.36: Imbued to some extent with the spirit of his age, he produced works at a great pace;
tgt_text.37: epigrams, grammars, and the so-called κτίσεις, i.e. poems on the origin and foundation of towns, but all these are lost to us save a few mutilated fragments and stray lines preserved in other writers.
tgt_text.38: In the library at Alexandria he remained until his death in B.C. 181, happy enough, no doubt, amongst the endless treasures of that vast repository of art and learning.
tgt_text.39: Of his work that has come down to us, too little notice has been taken by English scholars ;
tgt_text.40: for though his style at times bears too evident traces of laboured study, the structure of his poem is simple and straightforward.
tgt_text.41: The mind is not burdened by a multiplicity of episodes, the descriptions are singularly beautiful, and the similes, which are abundant and varied, show the hand of a master, who, if he did sometimes imitate, had at least something graceful of his own to add to what he borrowed, and not infrequently paid back his loan with interest.
tgt_text.42: The work found numerous commentators in ancient times, to whom we are indebted for the Florentine and Parisian Scholia.
tgt_text.43: Moreover, Apollonius was very popular among the Romans;
tgt_text.44: so much so that his poem was trans­ lated by Publius Terentius Varro Atacinus, and was imitated by Valerius Flaccus and many others.(i.) J. Lascaris. A.D. 1496. Quarto.
tgt_text.49: Little more than a reprint of the Florentine edition.(iii.)
tgt_text.55: Text with Latin translation and a few critical notes.(v.) G. Schäfer. A.D. 1810-13. 2 vols. octavo. Leipzig.
tgt_text.56: A better edition, and the first containing Paris Scholia.(vi.)
tgt_text.60: also the Scholia, and notes in Latin.(vii.)
tgt_text.62: A careful revision of the Laurentine MS., with notes.
tgt_text.63: There are, besides these editions of the actual text, certain German essays upon Apollonius, but in England hitherto this author has received but scanty justice.
tgt_text.64: T YRO, the daughter of Salmoneus, had two sons by Poseidon, Neleus and Pelias ;
tgt_text.65: she afterwards wedded Cretheus, son of Æolus, and bore to him Æson, Pheres, and Amythaon.
tgt_text.69: Now Jason was handed over to the Centaur Chiron to be brought up and to learn the art of healing;
tgt_text.70: while Æson, his father, left the kingdom to Pelias, his own brother, bidding him rule Thessaly until Jason's return from Chiron.
tgt_text.71: But Pelias had received an oracle from Apollo, bidding him beware of a man who should come with only one sandal;
tgt_text.72: for by him should he be slain.
tgt_text.73: So Jason grew up, and came to his uncle, for to take his share in his father's kingdom.
tgt_text.74: But when he came to the river Anaurus, which is in Thessaly, wishing to ford it, there upon the bank he found Hera in the disguise of an old dame, and she would cross, but was afraid.
tgt_text.75: Then did Jason take her upon his shoulders, and carry her safe over, but one sandal left he in the mud in the middle of the river.
tgt_text.76: Thence he fared to the city with his one sandal, and there he found an assembly of the folk, and Pelias doing sacrifice to the gods.
tgt_text.77: When Pelias saw him thus he minded him of the oracle, and being eager to be rid of him he set him this task, that he should go to Scythia in quest.
tgt_text.78: of the golden fleece, and then receive the kingdom.
tgt_text.79: Now this he did from no wish for the fleece, but because he thought that Jason would be slain by some man in that strange land, or be shipwrecked.
tgt_text.80: This is the story of the golden fleece.
tgt_text.81: A THAMAS, the son of Æolus, and brother of Cre­ theus, had to wife Nephele first, and begat two children, Phrixus and Helle.
tgt_text.82: When Nephele died, he married Ino, who did plot against the children of Nephele, and persuaded her country-women to roast the seed for sowing;
tgt_text.83: but the earth, receiving roasted seed, would not bear her yearly crops.
tgt_text.84: So Athamas sent to Delphi to in­ quire about the barrenness;
tgt_text.85: but Ino bribed his messengers, telling them to return and say, that the god had answered that Helle and Phrixus must be sacrificed if they wanted the barrenness to cease.
tgt_text.86: Wherefore Athamas was per­ suaded, and placed them at the altar;
tgt_text.87: but the gods in pity snatched them away through the air by means of the ram with the golden fleece;
tgt_text.88: now Helle let go, and fell into the sea that bears her name, while Phrixus landed safe in Colchis.
tgt_text.89: There he offered up the ram to Zeus, who helped his flight, for that he bad escaped the plot of his step­ mother.
tgt_text.90: And having married Chalciope, daughter of Æetes, king of the Scythians, he begat four sons, Argus, Cytissorus, Melas, and Phrontis.
tgt_text.92: There was a curse in the family of Æolus from the day that two members of it, Athamas and his wife Ino, ill-treated Phrixus and Helle, two other Æolids.
tgt_text.93: Zeus saved the two intended victims and put a curse upon the guilty family, which could not be revoked until the golden fleece was brought from Colchis to Hellas.
tgt_text.94: T HERE is no particular difficulty in following Argo on her outward voyage, or in identifying the numerous places mentioned by Apollonius along the route;
tgt_text.95: indeed, his knowledge of the geography up to Æa, the goal of the enterprise, is singularly accurate.
tgt_text.96: It is when we attempt to follow his account of the return journey, which was made by a different route, that we find ourselves utterly perplexed, and forced to the conclusion that our author has been drawing purely from imagination, without any idea of the impossibility of the course which he assigns to the heroes.
tgt_text.97: However, we purpose to give the route as described by the poet, noticing difficulties as they occur, though we shall not attempt to correct geographical errors in an account which by no conceivable theory can be reconciled with actual fact.
tgt_text.98: The expedition starts from Iolchos in Thessaly (i. 523).
tgt_text.99: The ship Argo is moored in the river Anaurus (i. 320).
tgt_text.100: Leaving the harbour of Pagasæ (i. 523), the Argonauts sail through the Sinus Pelasgicus, past the promontory of Tisa (i. 568) and the headland of Sepias (i. 582);
tgt_text.101: then coasting between the island of Sciathus (i. 583) and along the Thessalian coast, past the tomb of Dolops (i. 584), Melibœa (i. 592), the mouth of the river Amyrus (i. 596), Eurymenæ (i. 597), and the spurs of Ossa and Olympus (i. 598), they make right across the mouth of the Ther­ maic gulf to the promontory of Pallene (i. 599) ;
tgt_text.102: thence, after sighting Mount Athos (i. 601), they steer for Lemnos (i. 608).
tgt_text.103: After some stay in this island, they go out of their course to the isle of Electra or Samothrace, for the sake of certain mysteries (i. 916);
tgt_text.104: then keeping Thrace on the left of the ship and Imbros on the right, they sail across the Ægean Sea (i. 923) to the mouth of the Hellespont (i. 928).
tgt_text.105: Through the Hellespont they sail past Rhœteum, Ilium, Abydos, Percote, Abarnis, and so to Cyzicus, then an island, now mainland (i. 929 sqq.) in the Pro­ pontis.
tgt_text.106: Next they pass the mouth of the river Æsepus (i. 940) and come to the harbour and bay of Chytus (i. 987), but at this point they are caught by contrary winds and driven back again to Cyzicus (i. 1110).
tgt_text.107: Halting here awhile they go inland to ascend Mount Dindymus and spy out their further route ;
tgt_text.108: then go on again across the mouth of the river Rhyndacus in Mysia (i. 1165) until they reach the headland of Posideum (i. 1279), near to which live the savage Bebryces, whom they encounter and defeat (ii. 1 sqq.) at the mouth of the Bosporus.
tgt_text.109: Thence, after meeting the blind prophet Phineus in Bithynia (ii. 177), they pass through the dreadful Symplegades or Cyanean Rocks, which guard the entrance to the Euxine Sea (ii. 560 sqq.);
tgt_text.110: coasting along Bithynia (ii. 621) they pass the mouth of the river Rhebas (ii. 652), the rock of Colone, the Black Headland (ii. 653), the river Phyllis (ii. 654), the river Calpe (ii. 661), and anchor at the Thynian island (ii. 675).
tgt_text.111: Next they cross the mouth of the river Sangarius (ii. 724), passing the territory of the Mariandyni (ii. 725), the river Lycus, lake Anthemous, the river Acheron and its haven (ii. 726 sqq.);
tgt_text.112: thence past river Callichorus (ii. 906), the river Parthenius (ii. 938), Sesamus (ii. 943), Erythini, and the heights of Crobialus, Cromna, Cytorus and Carambis in Paphlagonia (ii. 945);
tgt_text.113: after this they pass Sinope (ii. 948), the river Halys (ii. 965), the river Thermodon (ii. 972), the Amazons and Chalybes (ii. 987 sqq.), the Tibareni, Mossynœci (ii. 1012 sqq.), land at the isle of Ares and rescue the sons of Chalciope (ii. 1033);
tgt_text.114: thence to the isle of Philyra (ii. 1234), past the territory of the Macrones, Becheiri, Sapeiræ, Byzeres, till they sight the range of Caucasus and the limit of their voyage (ii. 1245 sqq.);
tgt_text.115: they now enter the river Phasis, the river of Colchis, wherein lies the isle of Æa (ii. 1264).
tgt_text.116: The Argonauts have thus reached Æa.
tgt_text.117: Their voyage as sketched by Apollonius is singularly accurate, and it is clear that he must have been familiar with the geography to have given such an exhaustive list of places, hills, and rivers.
tgt_text.118: Briefly the voyage amounts to this.
tgt_text.119: The Argonauts leave the Pelasgicus Sinus (Gulf of Volo), coast along Thessaly to Ther­ maicus Sinus (Gulf of Salonica), steer across Ægæum Mare (Archipelago) to the Hellespont (Dardanelles);
tgt_text.120: through this strait into the Propontis (Sea of Marmara);
tgt_text.121: through the Bos­ porus into the Euxine (Black Sea).
tgt_text.122: Except when they cross the Archipelago, their voyage is almost entirely a coasting one, and is easy to follow on a map.
tgt_text.123: The return route retraces their steps as far as the river Halys in Paphlagonia(iv. 245), but then, instead of rounding theheadland of Carambis and following the coast-line (iv. 300), they strike out a new course across the open sea to the mouth of the Ister (Danube) (iv. 302).
tgt_text.124: From this point very little information is afforded us by Apollonius as to the places through which the heroes passed.
tgt_text.125: Certain names indeed are mentioned, but they are difficult to identify or localize, e.g., Mount Anchurus (iv. 323), the rock of Cauliacus (iv. 324), the plain of Laurium (iv. 326), the Brygian isles (iv. 330).
tgt_text.126: Apollonius was evidently aware of the weakness of his own geography, and avoids all details concerning this remarkable river-voyage ;
tgt_text.127: he eventually brings the heroes out into the Adriatic near the peninsula of Hyllis (iv. 524).
tgt_text.128: It is scarcely necessary to remark on the impossibility of this route, owing to rocks, rapids, cataracts, and an impassable current;
tgt_text.129: nor are we told into what river the Argonauts made their way out of the Ister in order to arrive at the Adriatic at all.
tgt_text.130: After this they steer towards the Italian coast, passing the islands of Issa, Dusceladus, Pityeia, Corcyra the Black (iv. 563), Melite, Cerossus, Nymphæa, and the Ceraunian hills (iv. 570 sqq.) ;
tgt_text.131: they come to the Eridanus (Po) (iv. 594), and apparently sailing right across northern Italy, gain by some unaccountable means the river Rhone (iv. 625).
tgt_text.132: Here again we are not informed how they achieved this remarkable feat;
tgt_text.133: the poet seems to labour under the delusion that the Eridanus and Rhone are connected, and that a continuous voyage is possible.
tgt_text.134: Next the heroes are somewhat vaguely said to pass through the territory of the Celts and Ligyans (iv. 645), but no further point on their course is mentioned until they arrive at the Stcechades Insulæ (Is. d'Hières, off the southern coast of Provence) (iv. 652);
tgt_text.135: thence they sail across the open sea (Mediterranean) to the isle of Æthalia, passing above Corsica (iv. 652), and so by a long coasting voyage along Italy they reach the Ææan harbour and the promontory of Circe (iv. 659);
tgt_text.136: thence passing the island of the Sirens (iv. 890) they come to the Æolian isles, run the gauntlet of Scylla and Charybdis in the straits between Italy and Sicily (iv. 920 sqq.), coast round the bottom of Italy, and land at Drepane, i.e. Corcyra, where the Phæacians live (iv. 980 sqq.);
tgt_text.137: from Drepane they coast along Epirus, Ambracia, and Acarnania, till they reach the Echinades Insulæ (iv. 1228);
tgt_text.138: but here they are caught by a violent tem­ pest and driven to the Syrtis Minor of Africa (iv. 1233).
tgt_text.139: Being unable to get out of the quicksands they carry Argo overland to lake Tritonis (iv. 1389), and, launching her again, sail out to sea.
tgt_text.140: Apparently they now made a very circuitous voyage along the coasts of Africa and Asia Minor until they were opposite to the island of Carpathus, which they are said to pass ;
tgt_text.141: from thence they came to Crete (iv. 1635);
tgt_text.142: thence through the Sporades into the Ægean to Ægina (iv. 1764);
tgt_text.143: then along the coast of Attica and between Eubœa and the Opuntian Locri (iv. 1779), through the Sinus Pelasgicus, to Pagasæ, whence they had started.
tgt_text.144: The return voyage teems with such insurmountable difficul­ ties, and is altogether so hopelessly confused and mythical, that it would be a mere waste of time and patience to attempt to follow it on a modern map.
tgt_text.145: We can only indicate briefly the course the heroes are said to have taken.
tgt_text.146: After crossing the Euxine (Black Sea), they rowed through river-ways right across Dacia, Mœsia, Illyria, and Dalmatia (Bulgaria, Servia, Bosnia, and Herzegovina), into the Adriatic;
tgt_text.147: sailing to Italy they cross the northern part by the Eridanus (Po);
tgt_text.148: sail into the Rhone, thence into the Mediter­ ranean ;
tgt_text.149: right across to the west coast of Italy, along which they pass ;
tgt_text.150: through the Lipari islands and the strait of Messina ;
tgt_text.151: up the east coast of Italy to the Adriatic again ;
tgt_text.152: thence driven by storms they come to the African coast;
tgt_text.153: being caught in the shoals of the Syrtis they carry Argo overland to lake Tritonis (Bahr Faraouni in Tunis), and finding an outlet into the Medi­ terranean, sail along the African coast to the coast of Asia Minor, and so into the Ægean homewards.
tgt_text.154: E PIC poets after Homer, and perhaps none more than Apol­ lonius, affect a singular licence in the use of possessive adjectives, and to a less extent of personal pronouns, confusing their strict meaning to such a degree, that it may be of some service to collect in a short scheme examples of Apollonius' more notable divergences from classical usage.
tgt_text.155: I. σφωίτερος, the possessive adj. of the 2nd person dual, does duty for-(a) Possessive adj. of 2nd person singular.
tgt_text.156: Cf. iii. 395.(/3) Possessive adj. of 3rd person singular.
tgt_text.158: iii. 335, 600, 625.(γ) Possessive adj. of 3rd person plural.
tgt_text.160: σφέτερος, the possessive adj. of 3rd person plural, does duty for-(a) Possessive adj. of 3rd person singular.
tgt_text.161: Cf. iii. 186, 622.(/3) Possessive adj. of 2nd person plural.
tgt_text.162: Cf. iv. 1325.III. tor, the possessive adj. of 3rd person singular, does duty for-(a) Possessive adj. of 2nd person singular.
tgt_text.164: iii. 140.(/3) Possessive adj. of 3rd person plural.
tgt_text.167: The personal pronoun of 3rd person singular does duty for-(a) 1st person singular.
tgt_text.170: Cf. i. 893.Pelias, in alarm, sends Jason to Colchis to fetch the golden fleece.
tgt_text.171: So Jason gathers the chieftains, and is chosen captain himself.
tgt_text.172: After launching Argo they sail on without adventure as far as Lemnos, where they stay awhile, and are hospitably received by Hypsipyle the queen.
tgt_text.173: Thence they come to the Doliones and their king Cyzicus, and are kindly entertained.
tgt_text.174: Giants withstand them at Dindymus, but these are shot by Heracles.
tgt_text.175: On the same night a storm drives the ship back to Cyzicus, and in the darkness they and the Doliones come to blows, and Cyzicus is slain.
tgt_text.176: After mourning for him, they sail on to Mysia, where Hylas is lost, and Heracles, who will not be comforted, is left behind with Polyphemus.w
tgt_text.177: ITH thee, Phœbus, will I begin and record the famous deeds of those men of old time, who, at the bidding of king Pelias, rowed the good ship Argo past the mouth of the Euxine and through the rocks Cyanean 1 to fetch the golden fleece.
tgt_text.178: For Pelias had heard an oracle on this wise, that in the latter days a hateful doom awaited him, even death at the prompting of one whom he should see come forth from the people with but one sandal.
tgt_text.179: And not long after, according to the sure report, came Jason on foot across the stream of a swollen torrent, and one sandal did he save from 'neath the mud, but the other left he there sticking in the river­ bed.
tgt_text.180: So he came to Pelias forthwith to take a part in the solemn feast, which he was offering to his father Poseidon and the other gods, but to Pelasgian Hera2 he paid no heed.
tgt_text.181: And the instant Pelias saw Jason, he was ware of him, and made ready to his hurt a grievous task of seaman- ship, that so he might lose his return in the deep or haply among strange folk.
tgt_text.182: Now minstrels even before any day do tell how Argus by the counsels of Athene built a ship for him ;
tgt_text.183: but mine shall it now be to declare the lineage and name of the heroes, and their passage of the long sea, and all that they did in their wanderings;
tgt_text.184: and may the Muses be the heralds of my song!
tgt_text.185: First then let us make mention of Orpheus ;
tgt_text.186: he it was, whom, on a day, as rumour saith, Calliope bare beside the peak of Pimpleia, her pledge of love to Thracian (Eager.
tgt_text.187: He, men say, did charm the stubborn rocks upon the hills and the river streams by the strains of his minstrelsy.
tgt_text.188: And wild oaks, memorials yet of that his singing, which he had led right on from Pieria by the spell, of his lyre, marched in ordered ranks, each behind his fellow, to range themselves, with all their leaves, upon the fringe of the Thracian shore.
tgt_text.189: So mighty a man was Orpheus, whom the son of Æson, by the counsels of Chiron, did persuade and take to help him in his toils from his kingship over Bistonian Pieria.
tgt_text.191: he it was whom Cometes did beget by the waters of swirling Apidanus, when he dwelt in Peiresia, hard by the Phylleian hill, where mighty Apidanus' and divine Enipeus do unite, flowing into one stream from their distant sources.
tgt_text.192: To these came Polyphemus,2 son of Elatus, having left Larissa;
tgt_text.193: who erst, what time the Lapithæ armed against the Centaurs, joined the fray as the youngest of the mighty Lapithæ.
tgt_text.194: Now on that day were his limbs weighed down with wine, but firm abode his warlike spirit still, even as aforetime.
tgt_text.195: No long space was Iphiclus, uncle of the son of Æson, left behind in Phylace;
tgt_text.196: for Æson had wedded his sister, Alcimede of Phylace;
tgt_text.197: whence the claims of blood and kith bade him enrol himself in the muster.
tgt_text.198: Neither did Admetus, lord of Pheræ, rich in sheep, abide beneath the peak of the Chalcodonian mountain.
tgt_text.199: Erytus and Echion too, sons of Hermes, well skilled in craftiness, and rich in broad cornlands, lingered not in Alope;
tgt_text.200: and yet a third arrived to join them as they were starting, Æthalides, their kinsman;
tgt_text.201: 1 him by the stream of Myrmidonian Amphrysus did Eupolemeia, maid of Plithia, bear;
tgt_text.202: but those other twain were sons of Antianeira, daughter of Menetes.
tgt_text.203: Came too Coronus, son of Cæneus,2 leaving rich Gyrton, a goodly man, yet scarce his father's match.
tgt_text.204: For minstrels tell how Cæneus, though he liveth yet, was slain by the Centaurs;
tgt_text.205: what time, alone and apart from the other chiefs, he routed them;
tgt_text.206: and, when they suddenly rallied again, they could not make him give way nor slay him;
tgt_text.207: but he, unconquered and unflinching, passed beneath the earth, smitten by the heavy pines they hurled on him.
tgt_text.208: Next came Mopsus, sprung from Titaron;
tgt_text.209: him the son of Leto had taught the augury of birds beyond all men;
tgt_text.210: likewise came Eurydamas, son of Ctimenus, who had his dwelling in Dolopian Ctimene, nigh unto the Xunian' lake.
tgt_text.211: Moreover Actor sent forth his son Menœtius from Opus, to go with the chieftains.
tgt_text.212: And Eurytion followed, and valiant Eribotes ;
tgt_text.213: one the son of Teleon, the other of Irus, son of Actor;
tgt_text.214: verily, famous Eribotes was sprung from Teleon, and Eurytion had Irus for his sire.
tgt_text.215: With these went a third, Oileus, matchless for chivalry, and skilled enow in rushing on the rear of the foe, what time their ranks give way.
tgt_text.216: From Eubœa Canthus hied him forth ;
tgt_text.217: he it was whom Canethus, son of Abas, was sending with eager feet;
tgt_text.218: yet was he never to turn again and reach Cerinthus.
tgt_text.219: For his fate it was with Mopsus, that skilled diviner, to wander to his death in the utmost ends of Libya.
tgt_text.220: For of evils none is too far away for man to meet therewith;
tgt_text.221: seeing that men buried those twain even in Libya, as far from Colchis as the rising and the setting of the sun are seen to be from each other.
tgt_text.222: Next then gathered to the muster Clytius and Iphitus, wardens of (Echalia, sons of Eurytus the harsh-that Eurytus, to whom the far-darting god gave a bow ;
tgt_text.223: yet had he no joy of the gift, for of his own choice he strove with the giver himself.
tgt_text.224: After these the sons of Æacus joined the quest;
tgt_text.225: they came not both together, nor from the same place;
tgt_text.226: for they dwelt apart, keeping aloof from Ægina, since the day, when in their witlessness they slew their kinsman Phocus.
tgt_text.227: Now Telamon had settled in Salamis, isle of Attica;
tgt_text.228: while Peleus went away and builded him a home in Phthia.
tgt_text.229: Next came the warrior Butes from Cecropia, the son of goodly Teleon, and Phalerus of the stout ashen spear.
tgt_text.230: Alcon, his sire, had sent him forth, albeit he had no other sons to nurse the evening of his life ;
tgt_text.231: yet for all he was his well-beloved,1 yea, his only-begotten, still would he send him to win renown among those heroes bold.
tgt_text.232: But Theseus, who far excelled all the sons of Erechtheus, did an unseen2 bond keep back beneath the land of Tænarus, for thither had he gone along with Peirithous.
tgt_text.233: Verily these twain might3 have made the accomplishment of their toil lighter for them all.
tgt_text.234: And Tiphys, son of Hagnias, left his Thespian folk in Siphas ;
tgt_text.235: a cunning prophet he to foretell a rising tumult amid the waves of the wide sea, and cunning to divine storms of wind and the course of a ship from the sun and the stars.
tgt_text.236: Him did Tritonian Athene herself rouse to the gathering of the chiefs, and he came amongst men eager for his coming ;
tgt_text.237: for it was Athene, too, that builded the swift ship, and with her had Argus, son of Arestor, fashioned it by her counsels.
tgt_text.238: Wherefore was Argo far the best of all the barques that ever crossed the sea with oars.
tgt_text.239: Next came Phlias from Aræthyrea, where he dwelt in plenty by the grace of Dionysus, his father, in his home by the springs of Asopus.
tgt_text.240: From Argos came forth Talaus and Areius, two sons of Bias;
tgt_text.241: and mighty Leodocus, whom Pero, daughter of Neleus, bare;
tgt_text.242: for her sake Melampus, son of Æolus, endured grievous misery in the steading of Iphiclus.
tgt_text.243: Nor are we told that mighty Heracles, stout of heart, made light of the earnest prayer of the son of Æson.
tgt_text.244: Nay, when he heard the report that the heroes were gathering, he changed his path anew from Arcadia and came to Lyrceian Argos, whither he was bringing alive a boar that battened in the glens of Lampeia 1 beside the vast marsh of Erymanthus ;
tgt_text.245: and he cast him down from off his mighty back, fast bound in chains, at the entrance to the assembly of the Mycenæans, while himself started off as he listed against the purpose of Eurystheus;
tgt_text.246: and with him came Hylas, his trusty squire, in the bloom of youth, to bear his arrows and to keep his bow.
tgt_text.247: Next came the son of divine Danaus, Nauplius.
tgt_text.249: he was son of Clytoneus, the child of Naubolus;
tgt_text.250: and Naubolus was the son of Lernus;
tgt_text.251: and of Lernus we are told that he was the son of Prœtus, whom Nauplius begat;
tgt_text.252: for the maid Amymone, daughter of Danaus, in days gone by, bare, from the embraces of Poseidon, Nauplius, who far excelled all men in seamanship.
tgt_text.253: And last of those, who dwelt in Argos, came Idmon;
tgt_text.254: for he would be there, although from augury he knew his fate;
tgt_text.255: lest the people should grudge him a fair fame.
tgt_text.256: He, of a truth, was no son of Abas, but the child of Leto him­ self begat him to swell the number of the famous race of Æolus ;
tgt_text.257: 1 yea, and himself did teach him divination, and to heed the flight of birds, and to read signs in blazing fire.
tgt_text.258: Moreover, Ætolian Leda sent forth from Sparta strong Polydeuces and Castor, skilled to curb fleet steeds;
tgt_text.259: these, her well-beloved sons, she bare at one birth in the halls of Tyndarus, and when they would go she said not nav, for her thoughts were worthy the bride of Zeus.
tgt_text.260: From Arene came the sons of Apharetus, Lynceus and Idas, of overweening pride, both too confident in their great strength;
tgt_text.261: and Lynceus too excelled in the keenness of his sight, if that is really a true legend, that he could see with ease a man even beneath the earth.
tgt_text.262: And with them Periclymenus, son of Neleus, started to go, eldest of all the children that were born to divine Neleus in Pylos ;
tgt_text.263: him Poseidon gifted with boundless might, and granted that2 whatsoever he should pray to be during the fray, that should he become in the stress of battle.
tgt_text.264: Again, from Arcadia came Amphidamas and Cepheus, who dwelt in Tegea, the heritage of Apheidas, the two sons of Aleus ;
tgt_text.265: and eke a third followed in their train, Ancaeus, whom his own father Lycurgus was sending ;
tgt_text.266: he was elder brother to those twain, but was left behind in the city that he might care for Aleus in his old age, but he sent his own son to join his brethren.
tgt_text.267: And the young man went on his way, brandishing the skin of a bear of Mænalus, and in his right hand a great two-edged axe.
tgt_text.268: For his grandsire Aleus had hidden his weapons in an inner closet, if haply he might stay him even yet from setting out.
tgt_text.269: There came too Augeas, who, legend saith, is son to Helios;
tgt_text.270: and over the men of Elis this prince held sway, glorying in his wealth;
tgt_text.271: but greatly did he long to see the land of Colchis and Æetes in person, the leader of the Colchians.
tgt_text.272: And Asterius and Amphion, sons of Hyperasius, came from Achæan Pellene, which on a day their grandsire Pelles founded on the crags by the sea-shore.
tgt_text.273: To these, again, came Euphemus, leaving Tænarus, he it was whom Europe, daughter of Tityus, of giant strength, bare, outstripping all in speed of foot.
tgt_text.274: He would run upon the sea's gray swell, and never wet his swift feet;
tgt_text.275: but, moistening just the soles thereof, he sped along his watery1 path.
tgt_text.276: And there came two other sons of Poseidon;
tgt_text.277: the one, to wit, Erginus, who had left the town of noble Miletus;
tgt_text.278: the other, Ancæus, the proud, who had come from Parthenie, seat of Imbrasian2 Hera;
tgt_text.279: both these boasted their knowledge of seacraft and of war.
tgt_text.280: Next came valiant Meleager, son of Œneus, having started from Calydon, and Laocoon too, who was brother of (Eneus;
tgt_text.281: yet were they not sons of one mother, but him did a bondwoman bear;
tgt_text.282: he it was whom Œneus sent, now that he was grown up, to guard his child;
tgt_text.283: so while yet a youth he entered that brave band of heroes, and none, me­ thinks, mightier than he had come, save Heracles alone, if he had stayed but one year 3 longer there and been trained up amongst the Ætolians.
tgt_text.285: his uncle Iphiclus, the son of Thestius, bare him company on that journey, a spearman good, and skilled enow as well to match himself with any in close fight.
tgt_text.286: And with him was Palaemonius, son of Lernus, of Olenus ;
tgt_text.287: son of Lernus men called him, but he drew his lineage from Hephæstus, wherefore he was lame of foot;
tgt_text.288: but none would have the hardihood to scorn his form and manliness, where­ fore he too was numbered amongst the other chiefs, swel­ ling the fame of Jason.
tgt_text.289: From the Phocians then came Iphitus, sprung from Naubolus, son of Ornytus;
tgt_text.290: now he had been Jason's host aforetime when he came to Pytho to ask an oracle about his voyage;
tgt_text.291: for there did Iphitus receive him in his halls.
tgt_text.292: Next came the sons of Boreas, Calais and Zetes, whom, on a day, Oreithyia, daughter of Erechtheus, bare to Boreas at the verge of wintry Thrace ;

tgt_text.296: and about their backs, from the crown of the head and on.
tgt_text.297: either side the neck, dark hair was waving in the breeze.
tgt_text.298: Nor yet had Acastus, son of stalwart Pelias himself, any longing to abide within his father's house ;
tgt_text.299: nor Argus either, servant of the goddess Athene;
tgt_text.300: nay, for they too, I ween, were to be counted in the muster.
tgt_text.301: This, then, is the tale of those who gathered to the son of Æson to aid him with their counsel;
tgt_text.302: whom the neigh­ bouring folk called Minyan chieftains, one and all, since most of them, and those the best, avowed them to be of the blood of the daughters of Minyas ;
tgt_text.303: even so Alcimede, the mother of Jason himself, was sprung from Clymene, a daughter of Minyas.
tgt_text.304: Now when the thralls had made all things ready, where­ with ships are furnished for their freight, whenso business calls men to make a voyage across the sea;
tgt_text.305: in that hour they betook them to the ship through the city to the place men call the headland of Pagasæ,1 in Magnesia ;
tgt_text.306: and around them a crowd of folk ran thronging eagerly;
tgt_text.307: but they showed like bright stars amid clouds, and thus would each man say as he gazed on them flashing in their harness:
tgt_text.308: “ King Zeus, what is the intent of Pelias ?
tgt_text.309: whither is he sending such a muster of heroes from out the Panachæan 2 land ?
tgt_text.310: They will sack the homes of Æetes with baleful fire the very day they see them, if so be he give them not the fleece of his own accord.
tgt_text.311: But the voyage may not be shunned, nor shall their toil be fruitless, if they go.
tgt_text.312: "So spake they, one here, one there throughout the city;
tgt_text.313: and the women lifted up their hands full oft toward heaven to the immortal gods, praying that they would grant the accomplishment of their return as their heart desired.
tgt_text.314: And one to another would thus complain through her tears:
tgt_text.315: " Ah, hapless Alcimede, to thee too hath sorrow come, late though it be, nor hast thou finished thy course with joy.
tgt_text.316: Surely Æson is a man of sorrows, and that in no small measure.
tgt_text.317: Yea, better for him had it been, if ere this he had been wrapped in his shroud3 and were lying 'neath the earth, a stranger still to evil enterprises.
tgt_text.318: Would that the black wave had engulfed Phrixus too, fleece and all, on the day that the maiden Helle perished!
tgt_text.320: that prodigy of ill uttered1 a human voice, that it might bring grief and countless woes to Alcimede, in days to come.
tgt_text.321: "Thus would the women speak as the heroes went on their way forth.
tgt_text.322: And many thralls, both men and maids, were already gathering, and his mother flung herself on Jason's neck.
tgt_text.323: For piercing grief had entered each woman's breast;
tgt_text.324: and with her his father, bowed by baleful age, made moan upon his bed, closely veiled from head to foot.
tgt_text.325: And Jason, the while, was soothing their grief with words of comfort;
tgt_text.326: but he signed to the thralls to take up his weapons of war, and they in silence and with downcast2 look took them up.
tgt_text.327: But his mother, so soon as she had thrown her arms around her boy, so clung to him, while her sobs3 came ever more thick and fast;
tgt_text.328: as when a maiden in her solitude is fain to cast her arms about her gray­ haired nurse and weep, one who hath none left to defend her, but she leads a cruel life under a step-mother, who ill­ treats her tender years with many a flout;
tgt_text.329: and as she weeps, her heart within her is held fast in misery, nor can she utter4 half the grief she yearneth to;
tgt_text.330: even thus was Al­ cimede weeping loud and long, as she held her son in her arms.
tgt_text.331: And in her affliction she spake this word:
tgt_text.333: would that I had straight given up the ghost and so for­ gotten my troubles, on the day I heard king Pelias declare to my sorrow his evil best, that thou, my child, with thine own dear hands mightest have buried me;
tgt_text.334: since that was all I yet could wish of thee, for all else that thy nurture owed I have long enjoyed.
tgt_text.335: Now shall I, who erst was so admired by the Achæan women, be left like a slave in my empty halls, miserably wasting away in longing for thee, over whom I once had much joy and glory, my only son for whom I loosed my maiden zone1 for the first time and the last.
tgt_text.336: For the goddess Eileithyia2 exceedingly did grudge me many children.
tgt_text.339: Little I reeked of this, even in dreams, that Phrixus would be an evil for me to shun.
tgt_text.340: "Thus was she, poor lady, sobbing and wailing, and the women her handmaids took up the wail in turn, but Jason spake to her softly with words of comfort:
tgt_text.341: " Mother mine, lay not such piteous grief on me thus all too much, for by thy tears shalt thou not keep from suffering;
tgt_text.342: nay, thou wilt join sorrow on to sorrow.
tgt_text.343: For the gods allot to mortals woes they cannot see.
tgt_text.344: Take heart to bear the lot of mortals for all thy heaviness of soul, and cheer thee with the solemn promise of Athene and with the god's answer, for very favourable was the word of Phœbus, and after these with the aid of the chieftains.
tgt_text.345: But now do thou with thy handmaidens abide quietly within the house, and be not a bird of ill omen to our ship;
tgt_text.346: for my clansmen and my thralls shall lead me on my way thither.
tgt_text.347: "He spake, and forth from the house started on his path.
tgt_text.348: Even as Apollo goes forth from his fragrant shrine through holy Delos, or Claros, or through Pytho, in his might, or wide Lycia by the streams of Xanthus;
tgt_text.349: in such beauty went he through the throng of folk, and there arose a-shout of men giving commands all together.
tgt_text.350: And there met him Iphias, the aged priestess of Artemis, protectress of the city;
tgt_text.351: and she clasped him by his right hand but could not , say a word for all her longing, since the crowd went hasting on ;
tgt_text.352: so she turned aside and left him there, as an old dame must before younger folk;
tgt_text.354: he passed by and was gone far away.
tgt_text.355: Now when he had left the streets of the town with their fair buildings, and was come to the headland of Pagasæ ;
tgt_text.356: there did his comrades welcome him, abiding together be­ side the ship Argo.
tgt_text.357: There she stood at the river mouth, and they were gathered over against her;
tgt_text.359: they saw Acastus and with him Argus coming forth from the city to them, and they marvelled to see them hasting thither with all speed, against the will of Pelias.
tgt_text.360: And the one, Argus, son of Arestor, had fastened about his shoulders a bull's hide, reaching to his feet, black, with the hair upon it;
tgt_text.361: but the other had a fair mantle of double woof, which his sister Pelopeia gave to him.
tgt_text.362: But Jason refrained for all that from questioning the pair on each point, but bade them seat themselves at the assembly;
tgt_text.363: for there were they sitting one and all in rows on furled sails and the mast that lay upon the ground.
tgt_text.364: And amongst them the son of Æson spake with good intent, "
tgt_text.365: For the rest, whatsoever a ship should be furnished withal lies ready against our start, for all hath been done well and in order;
tgt_text.366: therefore no long space will we hold back from our voyage on that account, when but the winds blow fair.
tgt_text.367: Nay but, friends, since our return to Hellas again is for all of us, and for all is the voyage to the land of Æetes, choose ye therefore now un­ grudgingly the best of you for leader, to whom each thing shall be a care, to take upon him our quarrels and our covenants with strangers.
tgt_text.369: and the young men looked round at bold Heracles sitting in their midst;
tgt_text.370: and with one shout they bade Jason declare him leader;
tgt_text.371: but he forthwith, from where he sat, stretched out his right hand and uttered his voice, "Let none offer this honour to me.
tgt_text.373: wherefore I will even stay another from rising up.
tgt_text.374: Let him who gathered us together, also lead the throng.
tgt_text.375: "So spake he in the greatness of his heart;
tgt_text.376: and they would have it as Heracles bade.
tgt_text.377: Then arose warlike Jason himself in his gladness, and to his eager listeners thus made harangue :
tgt_text.379: If then 'tis your will that your fame be in my hands, no longer let the voyage be delayed as hitherto.
tgt_text.380: Now forthwith let us appease Phœbus with sacrifice and make a feast at once;
tgt_text.381: and whilst my thralls, the overseers of my steadings, go forth, whose business it is to make good choice of oxen and drive them hither from the herd;
tgt_text.382: mean­ time will we drag the ship to sea, and do ye place all the tackling therein and allot the oars amongst the benches;
tgt_text.383: and let us the while build an altar on the strand to Apollo, lord of embarkation, who in answer to my prayer hath promised to declare and show the passage o'er the sea, if 1 haply by sacrifice to him I may begin my contest with the king.
tgt_text.384: "So spake he, and was the first to turn him to the work, and they rose up obedient to him ;
tgt_text.385: and they piled up their garments apart in rows on a smooth ledge of rock, over which the sea burst not with its waves, but long ago the stormy brine had washed it clean.
tgt_text.386: First then by the coun­ sels of Argus they lashed the ship stoutly with a well­ twisted cable from within, stretching it on either side, that the timbers might hold fast by their bolts and have strength to meet the breakers.
tgt_text.388: And quickly they scooped out a space as wide as the ship's girth encompassed, and about the prow into the deep they dug out all that she would take to run in, when they hauled her down.
tgt_text.389: And ever in front of the keel they kept hollowing deeper in the ground, and in the furrow did they lay smooth rollers, and on to the first of these they tilted her forward, that she might slide along them and be carried on.
tgt_text.390: And above, on this side and on that, they laid the oars across the ship, so as to project a cubit, and they bound them to the tholes;
tgt_text.391: while they stood there on either side at alternate oars and pushed with hand and chest together.
tgt_text.392: And amongst them went Tiphys to encourage the young men to push in time.
tgt_text.393: Loudly he shouted to urge them, and they at once leant on with all their might, and thrust her with one rush right from out her place, while with their feet they strained and strove ;
tgt_text.395: Pelian Argo went with them very swiftly, and they darted from her sides with a cheer.
tgt_text.396: Be­ neath her heavy keel the rollers groaned at the friction, and around them dark smoke and flame leapt1 up beneath the weight, and into the sea she slid.
tgt_text.397: Then did they check her onward course and held her with a rope.
tgt_text.398: And they fitted oars on both sides to the tholes, and laid the mast and shapely sails and stores within her.
tgt_text.399: Now when they had taken careful heed to each thing, first they portioned out the benches by lot, two men being told off to one bench, but the midmost bench, apart from the other heroes, did they select for Heracles and Ancæus, who dwelt in the citadel of Tegea.
tgt_text.400: For them alone they left the middle seat, at once, without casting lots ;
tgt_text.401: and with one accord they entrusted Tiphys to mind the helm of their ship with her good keel.
tgt_text.402: Next, hard by the sea, they raised a pile of shingle, and builded an altar there upon the strand to Apollo, naming it after him who holds the shore and favours those who go aboard.
tgt_text.403: And quickly they laid thereon logs of dry olive;
tgt_text.404: meantime, the herdsmen of the son of Æson drove before them from the herd two oxen ;
tgt_text.405: these the young men of his crew dragged to the altar, while others then held the lustral1 water and meal for sprinkling nigh.
tgt_text.406: And Jason called upon Apollo, the god of his fathers, and prayed, " Hearken, O king, who dwellest in Pagasæ and the city of Æson, that is called after my sire, thou who didst promise me when I sought to thee at Pytho to show me the accomplishment and end of my journey.
tgt_text.407: For 'twas thou thyself that wast the cause2 of the enterprise.
tgt_text.408: Do thou then bring my ship with my comrades safe and sound hither back to Hellas.

tgt_text.411: which we have set before thee;
tgt_text.412: a first gift, as an offering for our embarking on this ship;
tgt_text.413: and may I loose my cables with a harmless destiny through thy guidance, and may soft breezes blow, wherewith we may go in fair weather across the sea.

tgt_text.430: in that hour all strewed a deep couch of leaves upon the sand and laid them down in order before the gray sea's edge, and beside them lay vast stores of food and sweet mead, which cupbearers drew forth in beakers ;
tgt_text.431: next they told each other tales in turn, such tales as young men oft love to tell for their pastime1 o'er the feast and wine, what time the spirit of insatiate violence is far away.
tgt_text.432: Now the son of Æson the while was lost in wonder, and was ponder­ ing each matter within himself like to one downcast, when lo!
tgt_text.433: Idas noted him askance, and with loud voice railed upon him, " Thou son of Æson, what plan is this thou turnest over in thy heart ?
tgt_text.434: Speak out thy will here in the midst.
tgt_text.435: Is it fear, that bugbear of cowards, that is coming upon thee and mastering thee ?
tgt_text.436: Be witness 'twixt us now, my impetuous spear, wherewith I win myself renown far be­ yond other men in the wars, nor is it Zeus that helpeth me the half as much as this my spear,—yea, let it witness that there shall come no deadly woe, and that no task shall re­ main unaccomplished while Idas is with thee, even though a god should rise up against us.
tgt_text.437: Such a man am I whom thou art bringing from Arene to thy aid.
tgt_text.439: and grasping in both hands a full goblet drank off the pure sweet mead, and his lips and dark cheeks were wet with wine;

tgt_text.441: deadly are thy thoughts, even beforehand, for thyself.
tgt_text.442: Is it that the pure mead makes thy bold heart to swell within thy breast to thy undoing, and hath driven thee to slight the gods ?

tgt_text.444: Such a speech, 'tis said, the sons of Aloeus,1 men of old time, did sputter forth against the blessed gods;
tgt_text.445: and to them thou art nowise equal in manhood ;
tgt_text.446: yet were they both laid low by the swift arrows of the son of Leto, for all their bravery.
tgt_text.448: and Idas, son of Aphareus, laughed aloud his fill;
tgt_text.449: and, with blinking2 eyes, answered him with mocking words, " Come now, tell me this by thy divination, whether for me too the gods are fulfilling such another doom, as that father of thine gave unto the sons of Aloeus.
tgt_text.450: And devise thee how thou mayest safely escape from my hands, else shalt thou die for telling a prophecy light3 as the winds.
tgt_text.451: "Thus in his wrath he upbraided him;
tgt_text.452: and the quarrel would have gone further, had not their comrades and the son of Æson himself called to them with one accord and stayed them from their strife.
tgt_text.453: Then too Orpheus lifted up his lyre in his left hand and made essay to sing.
tgt_text.454: He sang how earth, and heaven, and sea, once all joined together in unity, were separated, each apart, after a deadly quarrel;
tgt_text.455: and how, for ever in heaven, the stars, and moon, and the paths of the sea have their steadfast goal;
tgt_text.456: and how the mountains rose up, and how rivers rushing noisily with their nymphs, and all creeping things came into being.
tgt_text.457: Next he sang how, at the first, Ophion and Eurynome, daughter of Oceanus, held sway o'er snow- capped Olympus, and how the one yielded up his honours to the mighty hands of Cronus, while she gave way to Rhea, and they plunged 'neath the waves of ocean.
tgt_text.458: Awhile did these lord it over the blessed Titan gods, whilst Zeus was yet a child and thought as a child in his home beneath the Cave1 of Dicte, for not yet had the earth-born Cyclopes made strong his hands with bolts of flashing lightning, for 'tis these that bring glory to Zeus.
tgt_text.459: He ended, and checked his lyre and voice divine;
tgt_text.460: but they, as he ceased, still leant their heads towards him with eager ears, one and all hushed but hungry still by his en­ chantment, so strong a spell of music had he left within their hearts.
tgt_text.461: But not long after did they mix libations for Zeus, as was his due, and piously poured them on the blazing tongues,2 and so bethought them of sleep for the night.
tgt_text.462: Now when the radiant Dawn with bright eyes looked forth upon the high mountain-tops of Pelias, and the headlands of the tossing main were swept into clear view before the breeze;
tgt_text.463: in that hour uprose Tiphys, and at once he bade his comrades go aboard and make ready the oars.
tgt_text.464: And strangely did the harbour of Pagasæ, yea, and Pelian Argo herself cry aloud, urging them to set forth.
tgt_text.465: For within Argo was laid one beam3 divine;
tgt_text.466: this it was that Athene made of oak from Dodona, and fitted all along the keel.

tgt_text.468: And in the midst sat Ancæus and Heracles, that mighty man, and nigh to him he set his club, and beneath his tread the ship's keel sank deep.

tgt_text.470: And Jason with a tear turned his eyes away from his fatherland.

tgt_text.472: even so they in time to the lyre of Orpheus smote with their oars the boisterous water of the deep, and the waves went dashing by, while on this side and on that the dark brine bubbled up in foam, boiling terribly 'neath the might of those strong men.
tgt_text.473: And their harness flashed like flame in the sunlight as the ship sped on, while ever far behind their course was white with foam, like a track seen over a grassy plain.
tgt_text.474: On that day all the gods looked down from heaven at the ship, and those men of courage half divine, who then were sailing o'er the sea, a picked crew ;
tgt_text.475: and upon the tops of peaks stood the Pelian nymphs, marvelling to see the work of Itonian Athene, and the heroes too, wielding their oars in their hands.
tgt_text.476: Yea, and from a mountain-top came another nigh unto the sea, Chiron,1 son of Philyra, and he wetted his feet where the gray waves break, and with his weighty hand he waved them on full oft, chanting the while as they went a returning free from sorrow.
tgt_text.477: And with him his wife, bearing on her arm Achilles, son of Peleus, sent a greeting to his dear father.
tgt_text.478: But when they had left the rounded headland of the harbour by the cunning and skill of Tiphys, wise son of Hagnias, who deftly handled the polished helm to guide the ship stedfastly, then did they set up the mighty mast in the cross-plank, and made it fast with stays, drawing them taut on either side, and they spread the sails upon it, stretching them along the yard-arm.
tgt_text.479: Therewith a fresh fair wind fell on them, so they fastened the ropes on the deck to polished pins, set at intervals, and quietly they sped beneath the long headland 1 of Tisa.
tgt_text.480: And for them the son of (Eager touched his lyre and sang in rhythmic song of Artemis, daughter of a noble sire, protectress of ships, who keepeth 'neath her care those peaks by the sea and 7 the land of Iolchos;
tgt_text.481: and the fishes darting beneath the deep sea, great and small together, followed bounding through the watery ways.
tgt_text.482: As when, in the track of the shepherd, countless sheep follow to the fold filled to the full with grass, while he goeth before them gaily piping some shepherd's madrigal on his shrill pipe ;
tgt_text.483: even so did the fishes follow with them, and ever onward the steady wind bare Argo.
tgt_text.484: Anon the misty2 land of the Pelasgi, with its many corn- fields, sank out of sight;
tgt_text.485: and past the Pelian cliffs they went, speeding ever onward;
tgt_text.486: then the Sepian3 headland opened to them, and Sciathus4 by the sea came in view, and in the distance were seen the Peiresian headlands and the headland of Magnesia, calm and clear upon the mainland, and the cairn of Dolops;
tgt_text.487: there they beached their ship at eve, as the wind veered round, and in honour of Dolops they burnt victims at nightfall by the swell of the heaving deep.
tgt_text.488: And two days they rested on the beach, but on the third they put forth the ship, stretching the wide canvas aloft;
tgt_text.489: wherefore men still call that beach the loosing place of Argo.
tgt_text.490: Thence onward they sped past Melibœa,1 seeing its black and stormy strand.
tgt_text.491: And at dawn they saw Homole close to them lying on the deep, and past it they steered, nor was it long before they were to sail away from the streams of the river Amyrus.
tgt_text.492: From thence they beheld Eurymenæ, and the sea-beat ravines of Ossa and Olympus ;
tgt_text.493: and then speeding on by the breath of the wind they reached at night the slopes of Pallene, beyond the headland of Canastra.
tgt_text.495: Now, as they fared on in the morning, the Thracian hill of Athos3 rose before them, which over­ shadows with its crest Lemnos, lying as far away as a well­ found merchantman could make by noon, even unto Myrine.
tgt_text.496: On the self-same day the wind blew on for them till nightfall, exceeding fresh, and the sails of the ship strained to it.
tgt_text.497: But at sunset, when the wind fell, they rowed, and came to Sintian Lemnos,4 rugged isle.
tgt_text.498: There had all the men-folk together been ruthlessly slain by the women's wanton violence in the past year ;
tgt_text.499: for the men had rejected their wedded wives from dislike, and had had a wild passion for captive maids, whom they brought from the mainland opposite from their forays in Thrace;
tgt_text.500: for the dire wrath of Cypris was upon them, for that they long had grudged her her honours.
tgt_text.502: hapless wives, insatiate in jealousy to your own grief.
tgt_text.503: Not only did they slay their husbands with those captives for their guilty love, but the whole race of men as well, that they might exact no vengeance thereafter for the pitiful murder.
tgt_text.504: Alone of all the women Hypsipyle spared Thoas her aged father, who indeed was king over the people ;
tgt_text.505: but him she sent to drift o'er the sea in a hollow ark, if haply he might escape.
tgt_text.506: Him did fisher-folk bring safe to an island, formerly called (Enoe, but afterwards Sicinus, from that Sicinus whom Œnoe, the water-nymph, bare from the embraces of Thoas.
tgt_text.507: Now to these Lemnian women, one and all, the herding of cattle, and the donning of bronze harness, and ploughing the wheat-bearing tilth was an easier lot than the toils 1 of Athene, whereat ever aforetime they busied them.
tgt_text.508: Yet for all that full oft would they peer across the broad sea in grievous dread against the coming of the Thracians.
tgt_text.509: Where­ fore when they saw Argo rowing near the island, forth­ with in all speed they did on their warlike gear, and poured down to the beach from out the gates of Myrine, like to Thyades who eat raw flesh, for they thought that surely the Thracians were come;
tgt_text.510: and amongst them, she, the daughter of Thoas, Hypsipyle, did on her father's harness;
tgt_text.511: and they poured forth speechless with dismay;
tgt_text.512: such dread was in their fluttering hearts.
tgt_text.513: Meantime forth from the ship the chieftains sent Æthalides,2 their swift herald, to whose care they entrusted their message and the wand of Hermes, his own sire, who gave to him a memory for all things, that waxed not old;
tgt_text.514: for even when he crossed the dreadful whirlpools of Acheron forgetfulness rushed not o'er his soul, but its portion is ever to change to and fro, now counted amongst those beneath the earth, now amongst living men in the sun-light.

tgt_text.535: How then will ye live, poor creatures?

tgt_text.544: "She spake, and called to Iphinoe sitting near, " Rouse thee, Iphinoe, I pray, and beg yon' man who leads their company to come unto us, that I may tell to him the word that finds favour with my people, and bid his company, if they will, set foot within our land and city boldly and with a good heart.
tgt_text.545: "She spake, and broke up the assembly ;
tgt_text.546: and then started to go to her own house.
tgt_text.547: And so Iphinoe came unto the Minyæ, who questioned her on what business bent she came amongst them.
tgt_text.548: And forthwith she thus made answer with all haste to their questions, " Verily, 'twas the daughter of Thoas, Hypsipyle, who sent me on my journey hither to call the captain of the ship, whosoever he is, that she may tell him somewhat that hath found favour with her folk ;
tgt_text.549: moreover she bids you, an you list, at once now set foot within her land and city with a good heart.
tgt_text.551: and welcome to all was her fair message.
tgt_text.552: Now they imagined that Hypsipyle, the well-beloved daughter of Thoas, did reign in his stead ;
tgt_text.553: so quickly sent they Jason on his way, yea, and themselves made ready to go.

tgt_text.564: and be­ hind him came Amphion,l singing aloud to his golden lyre, while in his track twice as large a rock followed.

tgt_text.583: but yet of himself and willingly he held her back, for he feared grievous quarrels for her love.
tgt_text.584: So he went on his way toward the city like a bright star, which maidens through their curtains, newly made, do see, when they awake, rising o'er their home, and through the dark mist it charms their eyes with its lovely blush ;
tgt_text.585: and the maiden is cheered in her longing for the youth who is amongst strange folk, for whom her parents are keeping her to be his wedded wife;
tgt_text.586: like to that star the hero stepped along the path before the city.
tgt_text.587: Now when they were come within the gates of the city, the maidens of the people surged behind them, glad to see the stranger ;
tgt_text.588: but he, with his eyes upon the ground, kept straight on, until he reached the glorious halls of Hypsipyle ;
tgt_text.589: and at his appearing maids threw wide the folding-doors, fitted with planks well wrought.
tgt_text.590: Then did Iphinoe lead him hastily through a fair hall, and seat him on a shining couch before her mistress;

tgt_text.592: yet for all her modesty found she wheedling word to address him withal:
tgt_text.593: " Strange sir, why sat ye thus so long outside our battlements ?

tgt_text.595: And I will tell thee truly all our trouble, that ye may know it surely for your­ selves.
tgt_text.596: When my father Thoas was king over the burghers, then did bands of our folk start forth and plunder from their ships the folds of the Thracians who dwell over against us, and hither they brought endless booty and maidens too.
tgt_text.597: But Cypris, deadly goddess, schemed a scheme, which cast upon them a fatal curse.
tgt_text.599: they loathed their wedded wives, and chased them from their homes, yielding to their folly, and they took for con­ cubines the captives of their spears, luckless wights !
tgt_text.600: Long time did we endure, if haply they might change their mind again at last;
tgt_text.601: but ever the evil went on and doubled, for they dishonoured their true children in their halls, and there grew up a bastard race.
tgt_text.602: And so maids unwed, and widowed mothers with them, went wandering in neglect through the city.
tgt_text.603: Nor did a father care ever so little for his daughter, though he saw her done to death before his eyes by the hand of an insolent step-mother ;
tgt_text.604: nor did chil­ dren ward off unseemly outrage from their mother as before, nor had brothers any thought for a sister.
tgt_text.605: But only captive maidens found favour at home and in the dance, in the place of assembly, and at festivals, till some god put overweening boldness in our hearts, that we would no more receive them in our battlements on their return from the Thracians, that so they might either be minded aright, or start and go elsewhither, captive maids and all.
tgt_text.606: Thereon did they demand all the male children that were left within the city, and went back again to the place where still they dwell on the snowy ploughlands of Thrace.

tgt_text.715: and withal upon the Dolionian folk fell the din of battle, terrible and furious.
tgt_text.716: Nor was he, their king, to rise above the doom of battle and come again home to his bridal chamber and bed.
tgt_text.717: Nay, him did the son of Æson, with one bound, smite through the middle of the breast as he turned to face him, and the bone splintered about his spear, and he grovelling on the sand wound up his clew of fate.
tgt_text.718: For mortal man may not escape his fate, but on all sides is spread a mighty snare around him.
tgt_text.719: Thus upon that night it caught him in its toils, as he thought, maybe, to avoid the bitter doom dealt out by the chieftains, what time he fought with them ;
tgt_text.720: and many other champions were slain.
tgt_text.722: and Acastus stript Sphodris of his arms ;
tgt_text.723: and Peleus laid Zelys low, and Gephyrus, that fleet warrior.
tgt_text.724: And Telamon of the stout ashen spear killed Basileus.
tgt_text.725: Idas slew Promeus, and Clytius Hyacinthus ;
tgt_text.726: and the two sons of Tyndarus slew Megalossaces and Phlogius.
tgt_text.727: Besides these the son of Œneus smote bold Itymoneus, yea, and Artaces, a leader of men ;
tgt_text.728: all these do the inhabi­ tants still honour with the worship due to heroes.
tgt_text.729: But the rest gave way and fled in terror, even as doves in flocks fly cowering from swift hawks, and they rushed headlong to the gates with loud cries ;

tgt_text.733: Three whole days they mourned, they and the folk of the Doliones together, tearing out their hair.
tgt_text.734: And then thrice about his tomb they marched in their bronze harness and made his funeral, and instituted trial of games, as was right, on the meadow plain, where to this day is his tomb heaped up for men that shall be hereafter to see.
tgt_text.735: Nor could his bride Cleite survive her husband's death, but in her grief she wrought a deed more awful still, what time she fastened the noose about her neck.
tgt_text.736: And the wood nymphs mourned her death, and all the tears they let fall to earth from their eyes for her, of these did the goddesses make a spring, which men call Cleite, the storied name of that poor maid.
tgt_text.737: Yea, that was the direst day that Zeus ever sent upon the men and women of the Doliones;

tgt_text.739: but they dragged on their life, eating the food, as it was, uncooked.

tgt_text.741: From thenceforth for twelve whole days and nights arose tempestuous winds, which kept them there from their voyage.
tgt_text.742: But on the next night, all the other chiefs, ere this, I ween, o'ercome by sleep, were resting there for the last time, while Acastus and Mopsus, son of Ampycus, guarded their sound slumbers.

tgt_text.767: Whence the Phrygians do ever seek the favour of Rhea with tam­ bourine and drum.

tgt_text.769: and signs, that are favourable, did appear.
tgt_text.770: Trees shook down countless fruits, and around their feet the earth of herself brought forth the flowers of tender plants.

tgt_text.772: And yet another marvel she produced ;

tgt_text.774: wherefore neighbouring folk in after time called that water Jason's spring.
tgt_text.775: Then did they make a feast in honour of the god­ dess on Mount Arctos, singing the praise of Rhea, august queen;

tgt_text.792: Now Heracles bade his comrades give good heed unto the feast, while he went on his way to the wood, that son of Zeus, that he might first fashion for himself an oar to suit him.
tgt_text.793: And in his wandering he found a pine that was not burdened with many branches, nor had much foliage thereon, but it was like some tall poplar sapling to look at both in height and girth.

tgt_text.795: And when he with his heavy club of bronze had made it totter from its base, then did he grip it low down about the stump with both hands, trusting to his strength, and plant­ ing himself firmly he leant his broad shoulder against it, and so clinging to it he dragged it from the ground, deep­ rooted though it was, clods of earth and all.
tgt_text.796: As when a sudden squall of wind strikes aloft a ship's mast unex­ pectedly, just at the time of baleful Orion's winter setting, and tears it from its stays,1 wedges and all;

tgt_text.798: And at once he caught up his bow and arrows, and his skin and club, and hasted to go back.
tgt_text.799: Meantime Hylas with a brazen pitcher went apart from the company, in quest of a sacred running spring, that he might ere his return draw for him water against supper­ time, and get all else ready and in order for him at his coming.
