tgt_text.1157: Wherefore it is that the Etesian winds blow cool across the earth for forty days from Zeus;
tgt_text.1158: and even now in Cos priests offer sacrifices before the rising of the Dog.
tgt_text.1160: and the chiefs abode there by con­ straint ;
tgt_text.1161: 5 and every day the Thynians sent forth good store of gifts for the strangers, out of favour for Phineus.
tgt_text.1162: After this, when they had builded an altar to the twelve blessed gods on the edge of the sea opposite, and had offered sacrifice upon it, they went aboard their swift ship to row away, nor did they forget to take with them a timorous dove, but Euphemus clutched her in his hand, cowering with terror, and carried her along, and they loosed their double cables from the shore.
tgt_text.1163: Nor, I ween, had they started, ere Athene was ware of them, and forthwith and hastily she stepped upon a light cloud, which should bear her at once for all her weight;
tgt_text.1164: and she hasted on her way seaward, with kindly intent to the rowers.
tgt_text.1165: As when a man goes wandering from his country, as oft we men do wander in our hardihood, and there is no land too far away, for every path lies open before his eyes, when lo!
tgt_text.1166: he seeth in his mind his own home, and withal there appeareth a way to it over land or over sea, and keenly he pondereth this way and that, and searcheth it out with his eyes;
tgt_text.1167: even so the daughter of Zeus, swifty darting on, set foot upon the cheerless strand 1 of Thynia.
tgt_text.1168: Now they, when they came to the strait of the winding passage, walled in with beetling crags on either side, while an eddying current from below washed up against the ship as it went on its way;
tgt_text.1169: and on they went in grievous fear, and already on their ears the thud of clashing rocks smote unceasingly, and the dripping cliffs roared;
tgt_text.1170: in that very hour the hero Euphemus clutched the dove in his hand, and went to take his stand upon the prow, while they, at the bidding of Tiphys, son of Hagnias, rowed with a will, that they might drive right through the rocks, trusting in their might.
tgt_text.1171: And as they rounded a bend, they saw those rocks opening for the last time of all.
tgt_text.1172: And their spirit melted at the sight;
tgt_text.1173: but the hero Euphemus sent forth the dove to dart through on her wings, and they, one and all, lifted up their heads to see, and she sped through them, but at once the two rocks met again with a clash ;
tgt_text.1174: and the foam leapt up in a seething mass like a cloud, and grimly roared the sea, and all around the great firmament bellowed.
tgt_text.1175: And the hollow caves echoed beneath the rugged rocks as the sea went surging in, and high on the cliffs was the white spray vomited as the billow dashed upon them.
tgt_text.1176: Then did the current spin the ship round.
tgt_text.1177: And the rocks cut off just the tail-feathers of the dove, but she darted away unhurt.
tgt_text.1178: And loudly the rowers cheered, but Tiphys himself shouted to them to row lustily, for once more the rocks were opening.
tgt_text.1179: Then came trembling on them as they rowed, until the wave with its returning wash came and bore the ship within the rocks.
tgt_text.1180: Thereon most awful fear seized on all, for above their head was death with no escape ;
tgt_text.1181: and now on this side and on that lay broad Pontus to their view, when suddenly in front rose up a mighty arching wave, like to a steep hill, and they bowed down their heads at the sight.
tgt_text.1182: For it seemed as if it must indeed leap down and whelm the ship entirely.
tgt_text.1183: But Tiphys was quick to ease her as she laboured, to the rowing, and the wave rolled with all his force beneath the keel, and lifted up the ship herself from underneath, far from the rocks, and high on the crest of the billow she was borne.
tgt_text.1184: Then did Euphemus go amongst all the crew, and call to them to lay on to their oars with all their might, and they smote the water at his cry.
tgt_text.1185: So she sprang forward twice as far as any other ship would have yielded to rowers, and the oars bent like curved bows as the heroes strained.
tgt_text.1186: In that instant the vaulted wave was past them, and she at once was riding over the furious billow like a roller, plunging headlong forward o'er the trough of the sea.
tgt_text.1187: But the eddying current stayed the ship in the midst of " the Clashers," and they quaked on either side, and thundered, and the ship-timbers throbbed.
tgt_text.1188: Then did Athene with her left hand hold the stubborn rock apart, while with her right she thrust them through upon their course;
tgt_text.1189: and the ship shot through the air like a winged arrow.
tgt_text.1190: Yet the rocks, ceaselessly dashing together, crushed off, in passing, the tip of the carved stern.
tgt_text.1191: And Athene sped back to Olympus, when they were escaped unhurt.
tgt_text.1192: But the rocks closed up together, rooted firm for ever;
tgt_text.1193: even so was it decreed by the blessed gods, whenso a man should have passed through alive in his ship.
tgt_text.1194: And they, I trow, drew breath again after their chilling fear, as they gazed out upon the sky, and the expanse of sea spreading far and wide.
tgt_text.1195: For verily they deemed that they were saved from Hades, and Tiphys first made harangue:
tgt_text.1196: " Methinks we have escaped this danger sure enough, we and the ship, and there is no other we have to thank so much as Athene, who inspired the ship with divine courage, when Argus fastened her together with bolts;
tgt_text.1197: and it is not right that she should be caught.
tgt_text.1198: Wherefore, son of Æson, no more fear at all the bidding of thy king, since God hath granted us to escape through the rocks, for Phineus, son of Agenor, declared that, after this, toils, easy to master, should be ours.
tgt_text.1199: "Therewith he made the ship speed past the Bithynian coast across the sea.
tgt_text.1200: But the other answered him with gentle words:
tgt_text.1202: Tiphys, why comfort my heavy heart thus ?
tgt_text.1203: I have sinned, and upon me has come a grievous blindness I may not cope with ;
tgt_text.1204: for I should have refused this journey outright at once when Pelias ordained it, even though I was to have died, torn ruthlessly limb from limb;
tgt_text.1205: but now do I endure 1 exceeding terror, and troubles past bearing, in deadly dread to sail across the chill paths of the deep, in deadly dread whene'er we land.
tgt_text.1206: For on all sides are enemies.
tgt_text.1207: And ever as the days go by, I watch through the dreary night, and think of all, since first ye mustered for my sake ;
tgt_text.1208: and lightly dost thou speak, caring only for thine 2 own life, while I fear never so little for my­ self, but for this man and for that, for thee and the rest of my comrades do I fear, if I bring you not safe and sound to Hellas.
tgt_text.1209: "So spake lie, making trial of the chieftains;
tgt_text.1210: but they cried out with words of cheer.
tgt_text.1211: And his heart was glad within him at their exhorting, and once more he spake to them outright, " My friends, your bravery makes me more bold.
tgt_text.1212: Wherefore now no more will I let fear fasten on me, even though I must voyage across the gulf of Hades, since ye stand firm amid cruel terrors.
tgt_text.1213: Nay, since we have sailed from out the clashing rocks, I trow there will be no other horror in store such as this, if we surely go our way, following the counsel of Phineus.
tgt_text.1214: "So spake he, and forthwith they ceased from such words, and toiled in rowing unceasingly, and soon they passed by Rhebas, that swiftly-rushing river, and the rock of Colone, and, not long after, the Black headland, and, next, the mouth of the river Phyllis,1 where aforetime Dipsacus received the son of Athamas in his house what time he was flying, together with the ram, from the city of Orcho­ menus;
tgt_text.1215: his mother was a meadow-nymph, and he loved not wanton deeds, but gladly dwelt with his mother by the waters of his father, feeding flocks upon the shore.
tgt_text.1216: And quickly they sighted and passed by his shrine, and the river's broad banks and the plain and Calpe with its deep stream;
tgt_text.1217: and day by day, the calm night through, they bent to their unresting oars.
tgt_text.1218: As ploughing oxen do toil in cleaving a moist fallow-field, and the sweat trickles in great drops from their flanks and neck, and they keep turning their eyes askance from under the yoke, while the parched breath from their mouths comes ever snorting forth, and they planting their hoofs firmly in the ground go toiling on the livelong day;
tgt_text.1219: like unto them the heroes tugged their oars through the brine.
tgt_text.1220: Now when the dawn divine was not yet come, nor yet was it exceeding dark, but o'er the night was spread a streak of light, the hour when men arise and call it twilight;
tgt_text.1221: 1 in that hour they rowed into the harbour of the desert Thynian isle with laboured toil, and went ashore.
tgt_text.1222: And to them appeared the son of Leto, coming up from far Lycia, on his way to the countless race of the Hyperboreans;
tgt_text.1223: and clustering locks of gold streamed down his cheeks as he came;
tgt_text.1224: and in his left hand he held his silver bow, while about his back was slung his quiver from his shoulders ;
tgt_text.1225: beneath his feet the island quaked throughout, and on the shore the waves surged up.
tgt_text.1226: And they were filled with wild alarm when they caught sight of him, and none dare gaze into the god's fair eyes.
tgt_text.1227: But there they stood with heads bowed low upon the ground, till he was far on his way to sea through the air ;
tgt_text.1228: then at last spake Orpheus, thus declaring his word to the chieftains, " Come now, let us call this island the sacred isle of Apollo, god of dawn, for that he was seen by all passing over it at dawn, and let us sacrifice such things as we may, when we have raised an altar on the strand ;
tgt_text.1229: but if hereafter he grant us a safe return to the land of Hæmonia, then surely will we lay upon his altar the thighs of hornèd goats.
tgt_text.1230: And now, as ye may, I bid you win his favour with the steam of sacrifice.
tgt_text.1231: Be gracious, 0 be gracious in thy appearing, prince!
tgt_text.1233: and some at once made an altar of shingle,2 while others roamed the island in quest of fawns or wild goats if haply they might see aught of either, such beasts as oft do seek their food in a wood's depths.
tgt_text.1234: And for them the son of Leto found a quarry;
tgt_text.1235: then with pious rites they wrapped the thigh bones 3 of them all in a roll of fat and burned them on the sacred altar, calling on the name of Apollo, god of dawn.
tgt_text.1236: And they stood in a wide ring around the burning sacrifice, chanting this hymn to Phœbus, " Hail, all hail!
tgt_text.1239: 1 while the goodly son of (Eager led for them their clear song on his Bistonian2 lyre, telling how on a day beneath Parnassus' rocky ridge he slew the monster snake Delphine with his bow, while yet a beardless youth, proud of his long locks.
tgt_text.1240: " 0 be gracious, ever be thy hair uncut,3 my prince, ever free from hurt, for thus 'tis right.
tgt_text.1241: Only Leto herself, daughter of Cams, fondles it in her hands."
tgt_text.1242: And the Corycian4 nymphs, daughters of Pleistus, oft took up the cheering strain, crying, "Hail, all hail! " 1
tgt_text.1243: This then was the fair refrain they chanted to Phœbus.
tgt_text.1244: Now when they had celebrated 6 him with song and dance, they took an oath by the holy drink-offering, that verily they would help one another for ever in unity of purpose, laying their hand upon the sacrifice;
tgt_text.1245: and still to this day there stands a temple there to cheerful Unity, the temple their own hands then built to the honour of a, deity most potent.
tgt_text.1246: Now when the third day was come, then did they leave that steep isle with a fresh west wind.
tgt_text.1247: Thence they sighted over against them the mouth of the river Sangarius,1 and the fruitful land of the Mariandyni and the streams of Lycus and the lake of Anthemoisia, and by them they passed.
tgt_text.1248: And as they ran before the breeze, the ropes and tackling throughout the ship were shaken;
tgt_text.1249: at dawn, for the wind dropped during the night, they were glad to­ reach the haven of the Acherusian headland, which rises up with steep beetling crags, facing the Bithynian sea;
tgt_text.1250: beneath it are rooted smooth sea-washed rocks, and round them the billow rolls and thunders loud, but above, upon the top, grow spreading plane trees.
tgt_text.1251: Further inland from this lieth a glen in the hollow, where is the cave of Hades,2 roofed in with trees and rocks, whence an icy blast, breathing always from the chill den within, ever freezeth the sparkling rime, that thaws again beneath the noonday sun.
tgt_text.1252: Never spreads silence o'er that grim3 headland, but there is a confused murmur of the booming sea, and of leaves rustling in the wind within.
tgt_text.1253: There too is the mouth of the river Acheron, which discharges through the head­ land and falleth into the sea eastward;
tgt_text.1254: a hollow chasm brings it down from above.
tgt_text.1256: called it in after-times " Saviour of Mariners," when they were about to settle in the land of the Mariandyni.
tgt_text.1258: it saved them and their ships when they were caught by a foul tempest.
tgt_text.1259: So now at once the heroes passed through the Acherusian headland and anchored insider just as the wind was dropping.
tgt_text.1260: No long time,2 I trow, could the slavers of Amycus, as report had told, anchor without the knowledge of Lycus, lord of that mainland, or of the Mariandyni;
tgt_text.1261: but they made even a league with them on that account.
tgt_text.1262: And they wel­ comed Polydeuces himself as he had been a god, gathering from all sides, for long time had they warred bitterly against the overweening Bebryces.
tgt_text.1263: And so it was that at once within the halls of Lycus they made ready a feast that day with all good will, going to the city, and rejoiced their hearts with converse.
tgt_text.1264: And the son of Æson declared his lineage and the name of each of his crew, and the commands of Pelias, and how they were entertained by the women of Lemnos, and all that they did in Cyzicus, city of the 'Doliones, and how they came to Mysia and Chios, where they left the hero Heracles against their will;
tgt_text.1265: also he declared the message of Glaucus, and told how they smote the Bebryces and Amycus, and of the prophecies and misery of Phineus, and how they escaped the Cyanean rocks, and met the son of Leto at the island.
tgt_text.1266: And the heart of Lycus was charmed at listening to his tale, and thus spake he amongst them all:
tgt_text.1267: " My friends, what a man is he whose aid ye have lost in your long, long voyage to Æetes!
tgt_text.1268: For well I mind seeing him here in the halls of my father Dascylus, what time he came hither afoot through the mainland of Asia, bringing the girdle of Hippolyte,3the warrior queen;
tgt_text.1269: but me he found with the down just sprouting on my chin.
tgt_text.1270: Then1 when our brother Priolaus was slain by the Mysians, whom from that day forth the people mourn in piteous elegies, he entered the lists with Titias the mighty, and vanquished him in boxing, a man who excelled all our young men in build and might;
tgt_text.1271: and he dashed his teeth upon the ground.
tgt_text.1272: Moreover he subdued to my father Phrygians and Mysians together, who inhabit the lands nigh to us, and took for his own the tribes of the Bithynians with their land, as far as the mouth of the Rhebas and the rock of Colone ;
tgt_text.1273: next the Paphlagonians, sprung from Pelops, yielded with­ out fight, all whom the black water of Billæus breaks around.
tgt_text.1274: But now the Bebryces and the violence of Amycus did separate me from Heracles, who dwells afar, for they have long cut great slices from my land, till they set their boundaries at the water-meadows of the Hypius.
tgt_text.1275: Yet have they paid the penalty to you, and I trow that he, the son of Tyndarus, brought not death this day upon the Bebryces without the will of heaven, what time he slew yon man.
tgt_text.1276: Wherefore now whatso thanks I can return, that will I right gladly.
tgt_text.1277: For that is right for weaklings, when others that be stronger than them begin to help them;
tgt_text.1278: so with you all and in your company I charge Dascylus my son to follow;
tgt_text.1279: 2 and if he go, verily ye shall meet with friends on your voyage as far as the mouth of Thermodon itself.
tgt_text.1280: Moreover I will dedicate to the sons of Tyndarus3 a temple high upon the Acherusian hill;
tgt_text.1281: to it shall all sailors seek when they see it in the far distance o'er the sea;
tgt_text.1282: yea, and hereafter will I set apart for them before the city, as for gods, fat lands on the well-tilled plain.
tgt_text.1283: "So then, the livelong day, they took their pastime at the feast, but at dawn they went down in haste unto the ship, yea, and with them went Lycus too, bringing countless gifts to bear away, for with them was he sending from his house his son to fare.
tgt_text.1284: There the doom of his fate smote Idmon, son of Abas, most excellent seer;
tgt_text.1285: yet could not his divining save him, for fate led him on to die.
tgt_text.1286: For within the water- mead beside the reedy river lay a boar, with white tusks, cooling his flanks and huge belly in the mud, a deadly monster, whereof even the nymphs that haunt the meads were afraid ;
tgt_text.1287: and no man knew of his being there, for all alone along the broad marsh he browsed.
tgt_text.1288: Now he, the son of Abas, was passing by the springs of that muddy river, when lo !
tgt_text.1289: the boar leapt up from some unseen lair among the reeds and charged and smote him on the thigh, cutting sinews and bone right in twain.
tgt_text.1290: And with one bitter cry1 down fell he upon the ground, and his comrades flocking round cried o'er their smitten fellow.
tgt_text.1291: But Peleus made one quick lunge with his hunting-spear at the boar as he darted in flight into the marsh, and out he rushed again to charge them, but Idas smote him, and with one grunt he fell grovelling about the sharp spear.
tgt_text.1292: And there they left him on the ground where he fell, and sorrowfully bare their swooning comrade to the ship, but he died in his companions' arms.
tgt_text.1293: So they stayed them from all thought of sailing, and abode in bitter grief for the burial of the dead man.
tgt_text.1294: Three full days they mourned, and on the fourth made him a splendid funeral;
tgt_text.1295: and the people, with Lycus their king as well, joined in the funeral rites ;
tgt_text.1296: and at the grave-side they cut the throats of countless sheep, as is the meed of the departed.
tgt_text.1297: So in that land this warrior's cairn was heaped, and upon it is a sign' for those who may yet be born to see, a log of wild olive such as ships are builded of, which putteth forth her leaf a little below the Acherusian head­ land.
tgt_text.1298: Yea, and if I must needs declare this also clearly in my song, Phœbus bade the Bœotians, who came from Nisæa, worship him, nothing doubting, as the protector of their city, and found a town about that log of ancient olive ;
tgt_text.1299: but2 these to-day do honour to Agamestor instead of Idmon, god-like son of Æolus.
tgt_text.1302: for yet again the heroes piled a barrow for a comrade dead.
tgt_text.1303: For verily there are yet two tombs of those two men to be seen.
tgt_text.1304: 'Tis said that Tiphys, son of Hagnias, died, for it was not appointed him to voyage further.
tgt_text.1305: Nay, a short illness closed there his eyes far from his fatherland,4 while his company were burying the dead son of Abas.
tgt_text.1306: And bitter was the grief they felt at this cruel woe.
tgt_text.1307: For when they had buried him too beside the other there, they threw themselves down in their distress before the sea, closely wrapped from head to foot, and never a word they spake nor had they any thought for meat or drink, but sorrow made their spirit droop ;
tgt_text.1308: for very far from their hopes was their return, and in their anguish would they have stopped from going any further, had not Hera put exceeding courage in the breast of Ancæus, whom Astypalæa bare to Poseidon by the waters of Imbrasus ;
tgt_text.1309: 1 for a right good steersman was he.
tgt_text.1310: So he did up anon, and spake to Peleus, " Son of Æacus, how can this be well to linger on in a strange land, neglectful of our enterprise ?
tgt_text.1311: Jason hath in me, whom he is leading from Parthenie away to fetch the fleece, a man whose skill in war is only second to his knowledge of ships;
tgt_text.1312: wherefore I pray you, let this fear for the ship be short-lived.
tgt_text.1313: Yea, and there be others here, men of skill;
tgt_text.1314: and whomso of these we shall set over the helm, none shall harm our voyaging.
tgt_text.1315: But quickly tell all this comfort out;
tgt_text.1316: then boldly rouse them to a remembrance of their labour.
tgt_text.1317: "So spake he, and the heart of the other went out to2 him in gladness;
tgt_text.1318: and anon, without delay, he made harangue in their midst, " God help us, sirs !
tgt_text.1319: why nurse we thus our grief in vain ?
tgt_text.1320: The dead, I trow, have died the death that fell to their lot, but there are amongst us, methinks, helms­ men in our company, aye, plenty of them.
tgt_text.1321: Wherefore delay we no more our attempt, but up to your work, cast­ ing sorrow to the winds.
tgt_text.1322: "To him the son of Æson made answer, much perplexed:
tgt_text.1323: " Son of Æacus, where then be these steersmen ?
tgt_text.1324: For they whom aforetime we boasted were men of skill, hang down their heads, more vexed at me than ever.
tgt_text.1325: Wherefore I fore­ see a sorry fate for us as well as for the dead, if indeed it be our lot neither to come to the city of baleful JEetes, nor ever again to pass the rocks and reach the land of Hellas;
tgt_text.1326: for here will a miserable doom hide us without fame, till we grow old for nought."
tgt_text.1328: but right speedily Ancæus took upon him to steer the swift ship, for verily lie was turned thereto by the prompting of the goddess.
tgt_text.1329: And after him arose Erginus and Nauplius and Euphemus, all eager for to steer.
tgt_text.1330: But these did they hold therefrom, for many of the crew would have Ancæus.
tgt_text.1331: So they went aboard on the twelfth day at dawn ;
tgt_text.1333: a strong west wind did blow for them, and quickly they passed through the Acheron with rowing ;
tgt_text.1334: and, trusting to the wind, they shook out their sails, and so sped calmly on a goodly stretch under canvas.
tgt_text.1335: Quickly came they past the mouth of the river Callichorus,l where, men say, the Nysean son of Zeus, what time he left the tribes of India and came to dwell in Thebes, held his revels and led the dance before the cave, wherein he would sleep away the gloomy' hours of sacred night, wherefore they who dwell around do call that river " Stream of fair dancing," and -that cave the Bedchamber,” 3 after him..
tgt_text.1336: Sailing thence they saw the tomb of Sthenelus,4 son of Actor, who on his way back from the bold fight with the Amazons-for thither had he gone with Heracles—died there upon the beach, of an arrow wound.
tgt_text.1337: So then they sailed on no further.
tgt_text.1338: For Persephone herself sent forth the spirit of the son of Actor, at his piteous prayer, to gaze a little on men of like passions with himself.
tgt_text.1339: So he took his stand on the summit of his tomb and watched for the ship, in form even as when he went to the war, and on his head shone his four-plumed helmet with the blood-red crest.
tgt_text.1340: And then he passed once more beneath the mighty gloom;
tgt_text.1341: but they marvelled at the sight, and Mopsus, son of Ampycus, did prophesy, and bade them anchor there and appease the spirit with drink-offerings.
tgt_text.1342: So they quickly furled the sails, and making fast the cables on the strand were busied about the tomb of Sthenelus, pouring libations to him, and offering sheep as victims.
tgt_text.1343: Moreover they did build, besides pouring libations, an altar to Apollo, pro­ tector of ships, and burnt sheep thereon;
tgt_text.1344: and there Orpheus dedicated his lyre, whence that place is called " the Lyre.
tgt_text.1345: "Anon, as the wind blew strong, they went aboard;
tgt_text.1346: and set the sail and made it taut to either sheet;
tgt_text.1347: 1 and Argo was carried at full speed to sea, even as when a falcon aloft through the air spreading his wings to the blast goes swiftly on his way, swerving not in his swoop, as he poises on steady pinions.
tgt_text.1348: And so they passed by the streams of Parthenius,2 murmuring to the sea, gentlest of rivers, wherein the virgin child of Leto doth cool her limbs in its lovely waters, whenso she ascendeth to heaven from the chase.
tgt_text.1349: Then speeding ever onward through the night they sailed out past Sesamus and the steep Erythinian hills, Crobialus, and Cromne, and wooded Cytorus.
tgt_text.1350: Next after doubling Carambis, as the sun was rising, they rowed all day and all night too along a vast stretch of sand.
tgt_text.1351: Anon they set foot on the soil of Assyria, where Zeus, tricked by his own promise, set down Sinope, daughter of Asopus, and granted her her virgin state.
tgt_text.1352: For verily he longed for her love;
tgt_text.1353: so the great god promised to give her whatsoever her heart desired;
tgt_text.1354: and she in her cunning asked her maidenhood.
tgt_text.1355: So too did she beguile Apollo, eager for her love, and after them the river Halys;
tgt_text.1356: nor did any man ever subdue her in love's embrace.
tgt_text.1357: There were dwelling even yet at that day the sons of noble Deimachus, prince of Triccæ, Deileon and Autolycus and Phlogius, after they had wandered away from Heracles.
tgt_text.1358: Now these, when they marked the expedition of the chieftains, came forth to meet them, and told them truly who they were;
tgt_text.1359: for they had no wish to abide there any longer, but went aboard the ship, soon as ever the clear' south-wind blew.
tgt_text.1360: So in their company they sped before the swift breeze, and left the river Halys, and Iris, that flows hard by, yea, and that part2 of Syria that these have formed;
tgt_text.1361: and on that day they rounded the distant headland of the Amazons, that shutteth in their harbour.
tgt_text.1362: There on a day the hero Heracles laid in ambush for Melanippe, daughter of Aretius, as she came forth;
tgt_text.1363: and, in ransom for her sister, Hippolyte gave him her dazzling girdle;
tgt_text.1364: so he set her free uuhurt.
tgt_text.1365: They then anchored in a bay behind the headland, at the. mouth of the Thermodon, for the sea was rising against their going.

tgt_text.2105: even so those twain were soon to tell out all their tale before the breath of Love.
tgt_text.2106: But the son of Æson perceived that she was scared by some bewilderment from heaven, and with a kindly smile he thus hailed her, " Why, maiden, art thou so fearful of me when I come alone ? .
tgt_text.2107: Verily I was never aforetime, not even when I dwelt in mine own country, one of those braggart fellows.
tgt_text.2108: Wherefore fear not ex­ ceedingly, maiden, either to question me or say what is in thine heart.
tgt_text.2109: Nay, but since we are met together as friends in this most holy place, where to sin were wrong, speak openly and tell me all;
tgt_text.2110: and deceive me not with comfort­ able words,1 for at first thou didst promise thine own sister to give me the drugs my heart desired.
tgt_text.2111: By Hecate herself, by thy parents, and by Zeus, whose hand is over strangers and suppliants, I entreat thee.
tgt_text.2112: As stranger and as sup­ pliant both, am I come hither to thee to implore thee in my sore need.
tgt_text.2113: For without thee never shall I achieve my dismal task.
tgt_text.2114: And I will make thee recompense hereafter for thy help, as is right, making thy name and fame glorious, as becometh those who dwell apart 2;
tgt_text.2115: yea, and in like manner shall the other heroes spread thy fame through Hellas on their return ;
tgt_text.2116: and so shall the heroes' wives and mothers, who now belike are sitting on the shore and mourning for us, whose grievous sufferings thou wilt scatter to the winds.
tgt_text.2117: In days gone by, Ariadne,3 daughter of Minos, did, of her good heart, free Theseus from his evil task;
tgt_text.2118: she it was whom Pasiphae, daughter of the Sun-god, bore.
tgt_text.2119: Yea,4 and she went aboard his ship with him and left her country, since Minos did lull his rage;
tgt_text.2120: and the im­ mortal gods showed their love as well, for there in mid sky is her sign, a crown of stars, which men call Ariadne's crown, wheeling by night amid the heavenly constellations.
tgt_text.2121: Such thanks shalt thou too have from the gods, if thou wilt save this famous host of chieftains.
tgt_text.2122: For surely from thy form, methinks, thou shouldst excel in gentle acts of kindness.
tgt_text.2124: and she cast down her eyes with a sweet smile,1 and her heart within her melted, as he extolled her.
tgt_text.2125: And she looked straight into his eyes, and had no word to answer him withal at first, but longed to tell him all at once together.
tgt_text.2126: And forth from her fragrant girdle she drew the drug ungrudgingly, and he with joy took it in his hands at once.
tgt_text.2127: And now would she have drawn her whole soul forth from her breast and given it him at his desire eagerly;
tgt_text.2128: so mightily did love light up his sweet torch from the son of Æson’s yellow locks, and snatched bright glances from her eyes;
tgt_text.2129: and her heart wasted and melted within her, as the dew upon roses melts and wastes away in the sun's beams at morn.
tgt_text.2130: But they would fix their eyes one time upon the ground in modesty, and then again would cast a glance at each other, with a smile of love in their glad eyes.
tgt_text.2131: At the last, and scarcely then, the maiden thus did greet him:
tgt_text.2133: Take heed now, that I may devise some help for thee.
tgt_text.2134: When my father hath given thee, at thy coming for them, the fell teeth from the snake's jaws to sow withal, then watch for the hour when the night is evenly divided in twain, and after washing thyself in the stream of the tire­ less river, dig a round hole, alone apart from the others, in sable garb ;
tgt_text.2135: there slay a ewe and sacrifice her whole, having heaped high the fire above the hole itself.
tgt_text.2136: And propitiate Hecate, daughter of Perses, the only-begotten, pouring liba­ tions of honey from a chalice.
tgt_text.2137: Then when thou hast taken heed to appease the goddess, draw back again from the fire;
tgt_text.2138: and let no sound of feet or howling of dogs drive thee to turn round, lest haply thou cut all short and come not thyself back duly to thy companions.
tgt_text.2140: then strip and with it anoint thy body as it were with oil;
tgt_text.2141: and there shall be in it boundless valiancy and great strength, and thou wilt think thyself a match for deathless gods, not for men.
tgt_text.2142: Moreover, let thy shield and sword and spear be sprinkled therewith.
tgt_text.2143: Then shall not the keen swords of the earth-born men cut thee, nor shall the flame of those deadly bulls dart forth resistlessly against thee.
tgt_text.2144: Yet shalt thou not be thus mighty for a. long space, but for that day only;
tgt_text.2145: yet never shrink thou from thy enterprise.
tgt_text.2146: And I will supply thee yet another help.
tgt_text.2147: So soon as thou hast yoked the strong oxen, and by thy might and manhood hast quickly ploughed the hard fallow, and they, the giants, at once spring up along the furrows when the teeth of the snake are sown over the dark soil, if thou but watch them rising in crowds from the lea, then cast secretly at them a heavy rock ;
tgt_text.2148: and they will destroy one another upon it, like fierce dogs about their food ;
tgt_text.2149: but be not thyself eager for the fray.
tgt_text.2150: Hereby shalt thou carry yon fleece to Hellas, far from Æa, I trow.
tgt_text.2151: Yet go, whither thou listest, when thou art gone hence.
tgt_text.2152: "So spake she, and dropping her eyes in silence before her did wet her cheek, divinely fair, with warm tears, mourning the day when he would wander far from her across the main.
tgt_text.2153: And once again she spake to him with sad words, taking hold on his right hand, for lo!
tgt_text.2156: Remember the name of Medea, if haply thou return one day to thy home;
tgt_text.2157: so will I remem­ ber thee when thou art gone.
tgt_text.2158: And tell me this in kind­ ness, where is thy home, where wilt thou fare from hence in thy ship across the sea ?
tgt_text.2159: Wilt thou go haply nigh to rich Orchomenus, or may-be toward the Ææan isle ?
tgt_text.2160: And tell me of the maid thou didst speak of, the far-famed daughter of Pasiphae,l who is of my father's kindred.
tgt_text.2161: "So spake she, and, as the maiden wept, love in his might stole o'er him as well, and thus he answered her, " Yea, verily, if I escape my fate, methinks I will never forget thee by night, nor yet by day, if indeed I shall escape scatheless to Achæa, and Æetes set not before us some other toil yet worse than this.
tgt_text.2162: But if it please thee to learn of my country, I will tell thee, for much doth my heart bid me myself as well.
tgt_text.2163: There is a land, ringed round with steep hills, rich withal in sheep and pasture, where Prometheus, son of Iapetus, begat goodly Deuca­ lion,2 who was the first to found cities and build temples for the immortal gods, and the first too to lord it over men.
tgt_text.2164: Hæmonia, the folk who dwell around, do call that land.
tgt_text.2165: Therein is Iolchos itself, my city, and in it too are many other cities, where men have not so much as heard the name of the Ææan isle 3;
tgt_text.2166: there is, indeed a legend that Minyas, of the race of Æolus, once started from thence and founded the town of Orchomenus, that borders on the Cadmeans.
tgt_text.2167: But why do I tell thee all these idle tales, and of our home and of famous Ariadne, daughter of Minos, for that was the glorious name men gave the lovely maiden, of whom thou askest me ?
tgt_text.2168: Would that, as Minos was then well pleased with Theseus for her sake, so too thy father might be at one with us!
tgt_text.2169: "So spake he, caressing her with fond and tender words.
tgt_text.2170: But grief, most bitter, stirred her heart, and in her distress she hailed him with earnest speech:
tgt_text.2171: " It may be that in Hellas these things are fair, to heed the ties of kin ;
tgt_text.2172: but Æetes is not such another amongst men, as thou sayest Minos, the husband of Pasiphae, was;
tgt_text.2173: nor can I compare with Ariadne;
tgt_text.2174: wherefore tell me nought of hospitality.
tgt_text.2175: Only do thou, when thou comest to Iolchos, remember me;
tgt_text.2176: and I will remember thee even in spite of my parents.
tgt_text.2177: And may there come to me from a far-off land some voice, or some bird with tidings, when thou hast forgotten me;
tgt_text.2178: or may the swift winds catch me up and bear me hence across the sea to Iolchos, that I may remind thee that thou didst escape by my aid, reproaching thee to thy face!
tgt_text.2179: Would I might then sit me down openly1 in thy halls!" .So spake she, shedding piteous tears adown her cheeks, but Jason caught her up2 there and said:
tgt_text.2181: leave the winds to wander emptily, and that bird too to bring thee tidings, for thy words are light as wind.
tgt_text.2182: For if thou ever come to those abodes and the land of Hellas, thou shalt have honour and respect amongst men and women, and they shall reverence thee even as a goddess, since their sons did return home again by thy counsel, yea, and many a brother of theirs and kinsman, and strong young husband was saved.
tgt_text.2183: And in our bridal bower shalt thou make ready our couch, and nought shall come 'twixt love and us, ere the doom of death o'er­ shadow us.
tgt_text.2184: "So spake he, and her heart within her melted as she heard, and yet she shuddered at the thought of that dark1 enterprise, poor maiden ;
tgt_text.2185: but she was not long to refuse a home in Hellas.
tgt_text.2186: For such was the mind of Hera, that Ææan Medea should come to sacred Iolchos, to the bane of Pelias, leaving her own country.
tgt_text.2187: But now were her handmaidens looking about for her silently at a distance, much distressed, for the time of day demanded the maiden's return home to her mother.
tgt_text.2188: But she thought not yet of going, for her heart rejoiced both in his beauty and his flattering words;
tgt_text.2189: but the son of Æson, seeing that it was now late, did say, " 'Tis time to depart, lest the sun sink before we know it, and some stranger get to know all;
tgt_text.2190: yet will we meet again at this tryst.
tgt_text.2191: "Thus far those twain made trial of each other with gentle words;
tgt_text.2193: Jason hasting back in joy to his comrades and the ship, and she to her handmaids ;
tgt_text.2194: and they came nigh to meet her in a body, but she heeded them not as they gathered about her, for her soul had winged its flight to soar amid the clouds.
tgt_text.2195: With random steps she mounted the swift wain, and in one hand took the reins and in the other the carven whip to drive the mules withal, and they dashed swiftly city­ ward to her home.
tgt_text.2196: Now when she was come thither, Chalciope, in agony for her sons, did question her;
tgt_text.2197: but she, at a loss through fear and doubt, heard never a word, and made no haste to answer her questions.
tgt_text.2198: But she sat her down on a low stool at the foot of the couch, leaning her cheek on her left hand, and her eyes were wet with tears, as she darkly pondered what an evil work she was sharing by her counsels.
tgt_text.2199: But when the son of Æson was again come among his comrades in the place where he had left them when he went away, he started to go with them unto the gathering of the heroes, telling them each thing;
tgt_text.2200: and together they drew nigh the ship.
tgt_text.2201: And the others did warmly greet him, when they saw him, and questioned him.
tgt_text.2202: And he amongst them all did tell the maiden's counsels, showing them the awful drug;
tgt_text.2203: only one sat alone apart from his comrades, nursing his rage, even Idas;
tgt_text.2204: but the rest in gladness, with peaceful hearts, were busying themselves the while about their beds, for dark night had stayed their hands.
tgt_text.2205: But at dawn sent they to Æetes two men, to ask him for the seed, first of all Telamon, great warrior, and with him Æthalides, Hermes' famous child.
tgt_text.2206: Forth on their way went they, nor was their journey in vain, for JEetes, the prince, gave them, at their coming, the fell teeth for the task of that Aonian 1 dragon, which Cadmus slew in Ogygian Thebes at its post by the Aretian spring, what time he came thither in quest of Europa;
tgt_text.2207: there he dwelt, guided thither by a cow,2 which Apollo vouchsafed to go before him on his way according to his oracle.
tgt_text.2208: These teeth the goddess Tritonis3 had drawn from the serpent's jaws, and given equally to Æetes and to Cadmus, who himself slew the monster.
tgt_text.2209: Now he, even Cadmus, son of Agenor, sowed his share upon the plains of Bœotia, and founded a race of earth-born men from the remnant left after the harvesting of Ares' spear;
tgt_text.2210: but the rest Æetes at that time readily gave them to bear unto the ship, for he never thought that Jason would make an end of his toil, even if he should cast the yoke upon the oxen.
tgt_text.2211: Far in the west the sun was sinking beneath the dark earth, beyond the farthest hills of the Ethiopians;
tgt_text.2212: and night was yoking his steeds ;
tgt_text.2213: so those heroes made ready their beds upon the ground by the hawsers.
tgt_text.2214: But Jason, soon as ever the stars of Helice, the bright Bear, did set, and all the firmament of heaven grew still, gat him to the wilderness, like some stealthy thief, with all that was needful, for by day had he taken thought for everything ;
tgt_text.2215: and Argus went with him bringing a ewe and milk from the flock, which things he took from the ship itself.
tgt_text.2216: But when he saw a spot, far from the tread of man, in a clear 1 water-mead beneath the open sky, then first of all he washed his tender body devoutly in the sacred river, and then put on a sable robe, which Hypsipyle of Lemnos erst gave him, in memory of many a night of love.
tgt_text.2217: Next he dug a hole in the ground, a cubit deep, and piled therein cleft wood, and cut the throat of the sheep and laid it carefully thereupon ;
tgt_text.2218: then did he kindle the logs by putting fire under, and he poured upon the sacrifice mixed libations, calling Hecate by her name Brimo to help him in his toil.
tgt_text.2219: So then he called upon her and then stept back, and she, that awful goddess, heard him and came to the sacrifice of the son of Æson from the nethermost hell, and about her on the branches of the oaks twined gruesome snakes, and there was the flash of countless torches, and the dogs of hell howled loudly round her.
tgt_text.2220: About her path all the meadows quaked, and those nymphs, that haunt marshes and rivers, and flit about that water-meadow of the Ama­ rantian Phasis,2 cried out.
tgt_text.2221: Yea, and fear took hold upon the son of Eson, but his feet brought him for all that without one glance backward, till he was amongst his comrades;
tgt_text.2222: and already Dawn, the child of morning, was rising above snow-capped Caucasus and shedding his light abroad.'
tgt_text.2223: In that hour Æetes buckled on his stiff 1 breast-plate, which Ares gave him, after he had slain with his own hand Phlegræan Mimas;
tgt_text.2224: and on his head he put a golden helmet, with four plumes, blazing like the sun's round ball of light, when he first rises from ocean.
tgt_text.2225: In one hand he wielded, a buckler of many hides, in the other a sword, dreadful, irresistible ;
tgt_text.2226: that blade could none of the heroes have withstood, now that they had left Heracles far behind;
tgt_text.2227: he alone could have stood up to battle against it.
tgt_text.2228: And Phaethon' held his shapely chariot with the fleet steeds nigh for him to mount;
tgt_text.2229: so he went up thereon and took the reins in his hands.
tgt_text.2230: Forth from the town he drave along the broad high-road, to take his station in the lists, and with him a countless throng hasted forth.
tgt_text.2231: Like as when Poseidon, mounted on his car, goeth to the Isthmian games, or to Tænarus,3 or cometh in his might to the waters of Lerna 4 or through the grove of Hyantian Onchestus, and with his steeds he cometh even to Calaurea, and the Hæmonian rock, or to wooded Geræstum;
tgt_text.2232: such was Æetes, captain of the Colchians, for to behold.
tgt_text.2233: Meantime Jason, by the advice of Medea, soaked the drug, and sprinkled his shield and weighty spear and his sword all over;
tgt_text.2234: and his comrades around him tested his harness with might and main ;
tgt_text.2235: but they were not able to bend that spear ever so little, but it remained hard and unbroken as before in their stalwart hands.
tgt_text.2236: Then did Idas, that son of Aphareus, in furious anger, hack the butt end thereof with his mighty sword, but the edge leapt from it like a hammer from an anvil, beaten back, and the others, the heroes, cheered in their joy, with good hope for his emprise.
tgt_text.2237: Next did he sprinkle himself as well, and into him there entered fearful valiancy, mar­ vellous, dauntless, and his hands on either side grew stronger, swelling1 with might.
tgt_text.2238: As when a war-horse, eager for the battle, leaps and neighs and paws the ground, and in his pride pricks up his ears and rears his neck;
tgt_text.2239: in like manner the son of Æson exulted in the strength of his limbs.
tgt_text.2240: And oft he sprang into the air, hither and thither, brandishing his shield of bronze and his ashen spear in his hands.
tgt_text.2241: Thou wouldst have thought 'twas lightning in winter-time, darting from the gloomy sky, and leaping, flash on flash, from out the clouds, what time they hurry in their wake the blackest storm.
tgt_text.2242: Now would they hold back no longer from their enter­ prise, but, sitting them in rows upon the benches, very quickly they rowed to yon plain of Ares.
tgt_text.2243: Now it lay over against the entrance to the town, as far therefrom as is the turning-post, which a chariot must win, from the starting- place, when at a prince's death his friends appoint contests for footmen and horsemen.
tgt_text.2244: There found they Æetes and hosts of other Colchians ;
tgt_text.2245: these were stationed on the Caucasian rocks, but he beside the river's winding bank.
tgt_text.2246: Forth leapt the son of Æson from the ship, with spear and shield, unto his task, so soon as his crew had fastened the cables;
tgt_text.2247: and with him he took a gleaming bronze helmet, full of the sharp teeth, and his sword slung about his shoulders, with naked1 body, somewhat resembling Ares, and haply somewhat Apollo with his sword of gold.
tgt_text.2248: One glance he took along the lea, and saw the bulls' brazen yoke and the plough, made of one piece of ponderous adamant, upon it.
tgt_text.2249: So he drew nigh, and fixed his strong sword upright to the hilt2 hard by, and set the helmet down resting against it.
tgt_text.2250: Then he set forward with shield alone, tracking the countless traces of the bulls, and they from some unseen den beneath the ground, where were their strong stalls, all wrapt in smoke and flame, rushed forth together, breathing flaming fire.
tgt_text.2251: Sore afraid were the heroes at that sight;
tgt_text.2252: but he, firmly planting himself,3 awaited their onset, as a reef of rock awaits the billows driven against it by the countless blasts.
tgt_text.2253: And in front he held his shield to meet them ;
tgt_text.2254: and they together bellowing, smote thereon with their strong horns ;
tgt_text.2255: yet they heft him up never a jot by their attack.
tgt_text.2256: As when the good leathern bellows of braziers now send forth a jet of flame through the holes in the smelting pot,1 kindling a consuming fire, and now again do cease their blast, while an awful roar goeth up therefrom, when it darts up from below;
tgt_text.2257: even so those two bulls did bellow as they breathed from their mouths the rushing fire, and all about Jason ran the consuming flame, striking him like lightning;
tgt_text.2258: but the maiden's spells protected him.
tgt_text.2259: Then did he catch the ox on his right hand by the top of his horn, and dragged him with all his might and main, till he was near the brazen yoke, and then he threw him down upon the ground on his knees with one quick kick2 against his brazen hoof.
tgt_text.2260: In like manner he tripped the other on his knees as he charged, smitten with one stroke.
tgt_text.2261: And he cast from him his broad shield on the earth, and kept those oxen twain where they were fallen on their knees, stepping from side to side, now here, now there, rushing headlong through the flame.
tgt_text.2262: But Æetes marvelled at the might of the man.
tgt_text.2263: Meantime those sons of Tyndarus,—for so had it been long before ordained for them,--came near, and gave him the yoke from off the ground to cast about them.
tgt_text.2264: And he bound it carefully upon their necks, and lifting the brazen pole between them, made fast its pointed tip unto the yoke.
tgt_text.2265: Then those twain started back from the fire toward the ship;
tgt_text.2266: but he once more took up his shield, and slung it on his back behind, and grasped the weighty helmet, full of sharp teeth, and his resistless spear, wherewith, like some labourer with a Pelasgian goad, he pricked them, thrusting beneath their flanks;
tgt_text.2267: and with a firm hand he guided the shapely plough- handle, fashioned of adamant.
tgt_text.2268: But the bulls, the while, were exceeding wroth, breathing against him furious flaming fire ;
tgt_text.2269: and their breath was as the roar of bluster­ ing winds, in fear of which sea-faring folk do mostly furl their wide sail.
tgt_text.2270: But yet a little while, and they started in obedience to the spear, and the grim fallow was cleft behind them, broken up by the might of the bulls and the strong plough­ man.
tgt_text.2271: Terribly groaned the clods withal along the furrows of the plough as they were broken, each a man's burden;
tgt_text.2272: and he followed, pressing down the left stilt with heavy tread, while far from him he was casting the teeth along the clods as each was tilled, with many a backward glance, lest the fell crop of earth-born men should rise against him ere he was done ;
tgt_text.2273: and on toiled those oxen, treading with their brazen hoofs.
tgt_text.2274: Now when the third part of day, as it waned from dawn, was still left, when swinked labourers call the sweet unyoking hour to come to them at once, in that hour the lea was finished ploughing by the tireless ploughman, for all it was four plough-gates;
tgt_text.2275: and he loosed the plough from the oxen, and scared them in flight o'er the plain.
tgt_text.2276: Then went he again unto the ship, while yet he saw the furrows free of the earth-born men.
tgt_text.2277: And he drew of the river's stream in his helmet, and quenched his thirst with water;
tgt_text.2278: and he bent his knees to supple1 them, and filled his mighty soul with courage, eager as a wild boar, that whets his tusks against the hunters, while from his angry mouth the foam runs in great flakes to the ground.
tgt_text.2280: now were those earth-born men spring­ ing up o'er all the tilth, and the acre of Axes the death­ dealer was all bristling with mighty shields and twy­ pointed2 spears and gleaming helmets;
tgt_text.2281: and the sheen thereof went flashing through the air from earth beneath to Olympus.
tgt_text.2282: As when, in the murk of night.
tgt_text.2283: after a heavy storm of snow hath fallen on the earth, the winds do scatter the wintry clouds once more, and all the heavenly signs at once are seen shining through the gloom ;
tgt_text.2284: even so those warriors shone as they grew up above the earth.
tgt_text.2285: But Jason remembered the counsel of crafty Medea, and caught up from the plain a great round rock, a fearful quoit for Ares I the War-god ;
tgt_text.2286: four strong men could not have stirred it ever so little from the ground.
tgt_text.2287: This did he take in his hand, and threw it very far into their midst with one swing, while himself did boldly couch beneath his shield.
tgt_text.2288: And the Colchians gave a mighty cry, like the cry of the sea when it roars on jagged rocks, but on the king Æetes came dumb dismay at the hurtling of that mighty quoit.
tgt_text.2289: Then did they like sharp-toothed 2 dogs leap upon it, and with loud yells did rend each other;
tgt_text.2290: and they were falling on their mother earth 'neath their own spears, like pines or oaks, which sudden gusts of wind do shake.
tgt_text.2291: Like as when a fiery meteor shoots from heaven, with a trail of light behind, a marvel to mankind, whoso see it dart and flash through the darkling air ;
tgt_text.2292: in such wise rushed the son of Æson on.
tgt_text.2294: and he bared his sword from the scabbard, and smote them, mowing them down one upon another, many in the belly and flanks as they were but half risen to the air, and some in the legs as they were rising, others just standing upright, and some as they were even now hastening to the fray.
tgt_text.2295: As when some yeo­ man, when a war hath broken out upon his boundaries, fearful lest men will ravage his fields, seizes in his hand a curved sickle, newly-sharpened, and hastes to cut his crop unripe, nor waiteth for it to ripen in its season by the beams of the sun;
tgt_text.2296: even so did he then cut the crop of earth-born men, and the furrows were filled with blood, as the channels of a spring are filled with water.
tgt_text.2298: some on their faces, biting with their teeth the rough clods ;
tgt_text.2300: others on the palms of their hands and sides ;
tgt_text.2301: like sea-monsters in shape to behold.
tgt_text.2302: And many wounded, or ever they had stept forth from the earth, bowed their damp brows to the ground and rested there, as much of them as had emerged to the air above.
tgt_text.2303: Even so shoots newly-planted in an orchard do droop to the ground, snapped from their roots, when Zeus sendeth a torrent of rain, a toil to gardening folk;
tgt_text.2304: and heavy grief and bitter sorrow cometh on him who owns the plot of ground and tends the plants.
tgt_text.2305: So then o'er the heart of king Æetes stole heavy grief.
tgt_text.2306: And he gat him homeward to his town.
tgt_text.2307: together with his Colchians, musing darkly how he might most quickly meet them.
tgt_text.2308: 1And daylight died, and Jason's toil was ended.
tgt_text.2310: but meantime Medea has fled to the Argonauts;
tgt_text.2311: and by her aid they have taken the fleece and gone.
tgt_text.2312: Absyrtus, son of Æetes, gives chase;
tgt_text.2313: but coming up with them is treacherously slain, at the mouth of the Ister, by Jason and Medea;
tgt_text.2314: whereat Zeus is angry, but Hera ever befriends them.
tgt_text.2315: Thence they come to Circe to be purified of the murder;
tgt_text.2316: and they pass through the Wandering Rocks," and through Scylla and Charybdis, and past the Sirens, all save Butes;
