tgt_text.2538: Never wouldst thou satisfy thy sweet longing in stroking it or gazing thereupon.
tgt_text.2539: And . the smell thereof was likewise wondrous sweet, from the day on which the prince of Nysa 1 himself lay down thereon, flushed with wine and nectar, with the fair form of Minos' daughter in his arms, whom on a day Theseus had left in the isle of Naxos, when she followed him from Crete.
tgt_text.2540: Now when Medea had declared her meaning to the heralds, so as to persuade them to depart, as soon as Absyrtus came by agreement to the temple of the goddess and night's black pall was over all, that so she might de­ vise with him a cunning plan whereby to take the fleece of gold, and come again unto the house of Æetes ;
tgt_text.2541: for, said she, the sons of Phrixus gave her by force unto the strangers to bear away.
tgt_text.2542: Thus did she persuade them, sprinkling the air and the breeze with magic drugs, such as can draw the wild beast from the pathless hill, be he never so far away.
tgt_text.2543: O cruel Love, man's chief est bane and curse !
tgt_text.2544: from thee proceed deadly feuds and mourning and lamentation;
tgt_text.2545: yea, and countless sorrows beside all these are by thee stirred up.
tgt_text.2546: TJp, and arm thee against the foemen's sons, thou deity, as in the day thou didst inspire Medea, with her fell murderous thoughts.
tgt_text.2547: But how did she slay Absyrtus by an evil doom when he came to her ?
tgt_text.2548: For that must our song tell next.
tgt_text.2549: When they had left her in the isle of Artemis, as had been agreed, then did these anchor their ships apart from one another;
tgt_text.2550: but that prince, Jason, went unto an ambush to await Absyrtus and his company.
tgt_text.2551: But he, tricked by their promises so dire for him, rowed quickly in his ship across the gulf of sea, as the night grew dark, and landed on the sacred isle.
tgt_text.2552: Straight on his way he went alone, and made trial of his sister with words, even as a tender child tries a torrent in winter, which not even strong men can pass;
tgt_text.2553: if haply she would devise some guile against the strangers.
tgt_text.2554: So they twain agreed together on all points, when on a sudden the son of Æson leapt from the thick ambush, clutching in his hand a naked sword;
tgt_text.2555: quickly the maiden turned away her eyes, covering them with her veil, that she might not see the blood of her brother when he was smitten.
tgt_text.2556: Him did Jason strike from his ambuscade, as a butcher strikes a mighty bull with strong horns, hard by the temple, which the Brygians, who dwell on the main­ land opposite, once had built for Artemis.
tgt_text.2557: There at its threshold he fell upon his knees, but as the hero breathed out his soul with his dying breath, he caught up in his hands black blood from the wound, and dyed with crimson his sister's silvery veil and robe, as she shrunk from him.
tgt_text.2558: But a pitiless spirit of vengeance, irresistible, gave one quick look askance at the murderous deed they wrought.
tgt_text.2559: Then the hero, the son of Æson, first cut off some limbs' of the murdered man, and thrice licked up some blood, and thrice spat the pollution from his mouth, for so must they make expiation who have murdered a man by treachery.
tgt_text.2560: Then he buried the clammy corpse in the ground, where to this day lie his bones amongst the Absyrtians.
tgt_text.2562: In the same hour the heroes, seeing before them a. blazing torch, the signal which the maiden raised for them to cross, laid their ship alongside the Colchian barque, and slew the crew thereof, as hawks drive flocks of doves in confusion, or fierce lions a great flock of sheep, when they have leapt upon the fold.
tgt_text.2563: Not one of them escaped death, but they fell on the whole crew, destroying them as fire doth;
tgt_text.2564: at the last came Jason up, eager to help them, but they had no need of his succour;
tgt_text.2565: but were already anxious on his account.
tgt_text.2566: Then they sat them down and took sage counsel about the voyage ;
tgt_text.2567: and as they mused thereon came the maiden to join them, and Peleus first made harangue:
tgt_text.2569: I bid you embark now, while it is yet night, upon the ship, and take the passage opposite to that which the enemy hold ;
tgt_text.2570: for at dawn, as soon as they per­ ceive all, methinks there is no argument which will urge them to pursue us further, so as to prevail with them;
tgt_text.2571: but they will part asunder in grievous quarrels, as men do who have lost their king.
tgt_text.2572: And when once the folk are divided, 'twill be an easy route for us, or indeed for any who come hither hereafter.
tgt_text.2573: "So spake he, and the young men approved the word of the son of Æacus.
tgt_text.2574: So they went quickly aboard and bent to their oars unceasingly, until they came to the sacred isle of Electra, chiefest of isles, nigh to the river Eridanus.
tgt_text.2575: Now the Colchians when they learnt the death of their prince, were right eager to search the Cronian sea through­ out for Argo and the Minyæ.
tgt_text.2576: But Hera restrained them by fearful thunderings and lightnings from the sky.
tgt_text.2577: And they ended by being afraid of their own homes in the Cytæan land for fear of Æetes’
tgt_text.2579: So they came to land in different places and settled there securely.
tgt_text.2580: Some landed on those very islands, on which the heroes had halted ;
tgt_text.2581: and there they dwell, called after Absyrtus ;
tgt_text.2582: others built a fenced city by the deep black stream of the Ulyrian river, where is the tomb of Harmonia and Cadmus, settling amongst the Encheleans;
tgt_text.2583: and others dwell upon the mountains, which are called " the Thunderers," from the day that the thunder of Zeus the son of Cronos stayed them from going to the island over against them.
tgt_text.2584: But the heroes, when now their return seemed assured them, did then bind their cables on the shore of the Hylleans and go forth.
tgt_text.2585: For there be groups of islands scat­ tered there, making the passage through them hard for sailors.
tgt_text.2586: But the Hylleans no more devised enmity against them, as before;
tgt_text.2587: but of themselves did further their voyage, getting as their guerdon Apollo's mighty tripod.
tgt_text.2588: For Phoebus gave to the son of Æson tripods twain, to carry to that far country, when he journeyed thither in obedience to an oracle, on the day when he came to sacred Pytho to enquire about this very voyage;
tgt_text.2589: and it was ordained that wheresoever these were set up, that land should never be ravaged by the attack of foemen.
tgt_text.2590: Where­ fore to this day that tripod is buried in yon land near the pleasant city of Hyllus, deep beneath the soil, that it may ever be hidden from mortal ken.
tgt_text.2591: But they found not king Hyllus still living there, whom comely Melite bare to Heracles in the land of the Phæa­ cians.
tgt_text.2592: For Heracles came hither to the house of Nausithous and to Macris, the nurse of Dionysus, to wash away the awful murder of his children;
tgt_text.2593: there did that hero vanquish in love's warfare the daughter of the river Ægæus, Melite, the water-nymph, and she bare strong Hyllus.
tgt_text.2594: But he, when he grew up, cared not to abide in the island itself, under the eye of Nausithous, its prince, but went o'er the Cronian sea, having gathered to him the people of the Phæacians who dwelt there;
tgt_text.2595: for the hero Nausithous helped him on his way;
tgt_text.2596: there did he settle, and was slain by the Mentores, as he stood up to do battle for the oxen of his field.
tgt_text.2597: But, ye goddesses, how came Argo's wondrous pennon in clear view outside the sea, about the Ausonian 1 land and the Ligystian islands, which are called " the line of isles ? " what need, what business brought her so far away ?
tgt_text.2599: Zeus, I trow, the king of gods, was seized with fury at their deed, when Absyrtus was mightily o’erthrown ;
tgt_text.2600: but yet he ordained that they should wash away the guilt of blood by the counsels of Ææan Circe, and after first en­ during countless woes should return.
tgt_text.2601: Now none of the chieftains was ware thereof;
tgt_text.2602: but starting from the land of Hyllus they hasted far on their way, and they left on the lee those islands of the Liburni that lie in order on the sea, peopled formerly by Colchians, Issa and Dusceladus and lovely Pityeia.
tgt_text.2603: And, next to them, they came unto Corcyra, where Poseidon had settled the daughter of Asopus, Cor­ cyra of the fair tresses, far from the land of Phlius, whence he had snatched her in his love;
tgt_text.2604: and sailors, seeing it rise darkly from the main with black woodland all around, do call it Corcyra the Black.
tgt_text.2605: Next passed they Melite, rejoicing greatly at the gentle breeze, and steep Cerossus, and Nymphæa on the far horizon, where queen Calypso, daughter of Atlas, had her home;
tgt_text.2607: they deemed they saw the shadowy " hills of thunder."
tgt_text.2608: Then was Hera ware of the angry counsels and the heavy wrath of Zeus for their sake;
tgt_text.2609: and forasmuch as she was planning the fulfilment of that voyage, she did stir up head-winds,2 whereby they were caught and carried back upon the rocky isle of Electra.
tgt_text.2610: Anon from out the hollow ship, in mid course, the oaken beam from Dodona, which Athene had fitted down the middle of the keel, found a tongue and cried out in human voice.
tgt_text.2611: And deadly fear came on them as they heard the voice, that told of Zeus's grievous wrath.
tgt_text.2612: For it said they should not escape a passage o'er a lengthy sea, nor troublous tempests, unless Circe purged them of the ruthless murder of Absyrtus;
tgt_text.2613: and it bade Polydeuces and Castor pray to the deathless gods to grant a passage first across the Ausonian sea, wherein they should find Circe, daughter of Perse and Helios.
tgt_text.2614: So cried Argo in the gloom ;
tgt_text.2615: and they, the sons of Tyn­ darus, arose, and raised their hands to the immortals, praying for each and all;
tgt_text.2616: for deep dismay was come upon the other Minyan heroes.
tgt_text.2617: But the ship sped on apace;
tgt_text.2618: and they entered far into the stream of Eridanus, where on a day Phaethon, smitten through the breast with a blazing bolt, fell scorched from the chariot of Helios into the mouth of that deep sheet of water, and it belches forth heavy.
tgt_text.2619: clouds of steam from his wound that still is smouldering.
tgt_text.2620: No bird can spread his light pinions and cross that water, but half-way it flutters and then plunges in the flame.
tgt_text.2621: Round about the daughters of the Sun sadly raise their dirge of woe, as they dance round the tall poplars;
tgt_text.2622: and from their eyes they shed upon the ground bright drops of amber, which dry up on the sand beneath the sun's heat;
tgt_text.2623: but when the swollen billows of the dark mere do dash against the rocks before the blast of the noisy wind, then are they rolled all together along the billowy tide into the Eridanus.
tgt_text.2624: And the Celts have set this legend to them, how that they are the tears of Apollo, son of Leto, hurried away in the swirling stream, all those many tears he shed the day he came to the sacred race of the Hyperboreans,1 leaving .radiant heaven at the chiding of his father, wroth at the slaying of his son, whom divine Coronis bare in rich Lacereia by the mouth of the Amyrus.
tgt_text.2625: So runs the legend ’mongst those folk.
tgt_text.2626: But these felt no desire for meat or drink, nor did their spirit turn to mirth.
tgt_text.2627: But all day, I trow, were they worn out and grievously weakened by the foul stench, which the streams of Eridanus sent up unceas­ ingly from smouldering Phaethon;
tgt_text.2628: and all night too they heard the shrill lament of the daughters of the Sun, loudly wailing;
tgt_text.2629: and as they mourned their tears were borne along the waters, as it were drops of oil.
tgt_text.2630: Thence they entered the deep stream of Bhodanus, which comes to join the Eridanus;
tgt_text.2631: and at their meeting doth the water roar in wild commotion.
tgt_text.2632: Now that river, rising in a land very far away, where are the portals and .
tgt_text.2633: the habitation of Night, doth pour himself on one side upon the ocean's cliffs, on another doth he fall into the Ionian sea, while by yet a third channel he casts his stream through seven mouths into the Sardinian sea and its boundless bay.
tgt_text.2634: Thence they sailed into stormy lakes, which open out along the vast mainland of the Celts, and there would they have met with a foul mishap.
tgt_text.2635: For a certain off-stream was bearing them into the ocean-gulf, and.
tgt_text.2636: they not knowing were about to sail thereinto;
tgt_text.2637: whence they would never have won a safe return.
tgt_text.2638: But Hera sped forth from heaven and shouted from the Hercynian rock;
tgt_text.2639: and one and all did quake with fear at her shout, for terribly rumbled the wide firmament.
tgt_text.2640: So they turned back before the goddess, noting now the way along which they must go for their return.
tgt_text.2641: At last they reached the sea-coast by the counsels of Hera, passing through the coasts of countless Celtic and Ligyan tribes, without being attacked.
tgt_text.2642: For about them the goddess shed a thick mist all day as they went.
tgt_text.2643: So they sailed through the river's midmost mouth and came unto " the line of islands," saved through the intercession of the sons of Zeus;
tgt_text.2644: wherefore are altars and temples builded there for ever, for it was not that voyage alone they did attend to succour;
tgt_text.2645: but to them Zeus vouchsafed to aid the ships also of future mariners.
tgt_text.2646: After leaving the line of islands" they sailed to the isle of Æthalia, and there1 upon its shingly beach they wiped off in the lists much sweat;
tgt_text.2647: and the pebbles on the strand were strewn as it were with skin;
tgt_text.2648: and there lie their quoits and tattered raiment, wondrous many;
tgt_text.2649: so that the harbour therein is called Argo's haven after them.
tgt_text.2650: Quickly they sailed thence across the ocean swell with their eyes upon the Tyrsenian cliffs of Ausonia, and came unto the famous harbour of Ææa, and they drew nigh and fastened the ship's hawsers on the rocks.
tgt_text.2651: There they found Circe washing her head in the sea-water, for greatly was she scared by the visions of the night.
tgt_text.2652: Her chamber and the walls of her house seemed to be all running with blood, and fire was devouring her store of drugs, where­ with afore she bewitched strangers, whoso came hither;
tgt_text.2653: and she did quench the fire's bright blaze with blood of murdered men, scooping it up in her hands;
tgt_text.2654: and so she ceased from deadly fear.
tgt_text.2656: Wherefore so soon as dawn was come, she arose and would wash her hair and raiment in the waters of the sea.
tgt_text.2657: And beasts, that resembled not ravening brutes of prey, nor yet had the form of men, but each wore his fellow's limbs in medley strange, came trooping forth, like sheep when they throng from the fold at the heels of the shepherd.
tgt_text.2658: Such creatures earth herself produced from the primeval mud,2 compact of divers kinds of limbs, when as yet she was not made solid by the thirsty air, nor yet had gotten one drop of moisture from the rays of the scorching sun;
tgt_text.2659: but time put these forms together and led them forth in rows;
tgt_text.2660: e'en such were the shapeless things that followed her.
tgt_text.2661: And exceeding wonder seized the heroes ;
tgt_text.2662: and anon, as each man gazed upon the form and face of Circe, easily he guessed she was a sister of Æetes.
tgt_text.2663: Now when she had sent from her the terror of her dream by night, at once she started back again, and she bade them follow her in her subtlety, caressing them with her hand.
tgt_text.2664: Now his company abode there steadfastly at the bidding of the son of Æson, but he took with him the Colchian maiden;
tgt_text.2665: and they twain went with her along the road, until they came to the hall of Circe;
tgt_text.2666: then that lady bade them sit on fair seats, in great amaze at their coming.
tgt_text.2667: But those twain without a word or sound darted to her hearth and sat them down, as is the custom of sad sup- pliants, and Medea buried her face in her hands, but Jason fixed his great hilted sword in the ground, where­ with he slew the son of Æetes, but his eye would never look her full in the face.
tgt_text.2668: In that moment Circe knew, 'twas murder and blood-guiltiness from which they fled.
tgt_text.2669: Wherefore in reverence for the ordinance of Zeus, the sup­ pliants' god, who is a very jealous god, yet mightily suc­ coureth murderers, she offered the sacrifice, wherewith ruthless suppliants purify themselves when they come to the altar.
tgt_text.2670: First, to release them from the unatoned bloodshed, she held above their heads the young of a sow, whose dugs were still full of milk after her litter, and wetted their hands in the blood when she had cut its skin ;
tgt_text.2671: next made she atonement with other libations, call­ ing on Zeus the while to purify them;
tgt_text.2672: for he is the champion of blood-guilty suppliants.
tgt_text.2673: And all that she used in the cleansing did attendant nymphs, who brought each thing to her, bear forth from the house.
tgt_text.2674: But she within stood by the hearth and burned thereon, praying the while, a soothing sop of honey, oil, and meal with nought of wine1 therein, that she might stay the grim spirits of vengeance from their fury, and that Zeus might be propitious and favourable to them both, whether they sought atonement for hands defiled with a stranger's blood or haply for a kinsman, themselves his kith and kin.
tgt_text.2675: Now when all her task was duly done, then did she raise them up, and seated them on polished chairs, and herself sat near facing them.
tgt_text.2676: And straightway she ques­ tioned them straitly of their business and their voyage, and whence they came to her land and house, to sit them down as suppliants in such wise.
tgt_text.2678: a hideous re- membrance of her dream came o'er her, as her heart mused thereon;
tgt_text.2679: and she yearned to hear the voice of the maiden, her kinswoman, soon as ever she saw her lift her eyes from the ground.
tgt_text.2680: For all the race of Helios was manifest at sight, for they shot far in front of them a gleam, as it had been of gold, from the twinkling of their eyes.
tgt_text.2681: Then did she, the daughter of grave Æetes, make soft answer in the Colchian tongue to all her questioning, telling of the expedition and the journey of the heroes, and all their suffering in their hurried toils, and how she had sinned at the bidding of her sorrowing sister, and how she fled with the sons of Phrixus from the awful horrors her father might inflict;
tgt_text.2682: but of the murder of Absyrtus she was careful not to speak.
tgt_text.2683: But nowise did it escape the ken of Circe;
tgt_text.2684: yet for all that she pitied the weeping maiden, and thus unto her said, " Unhappy girl!
tgt_text.2685: verily an evil and a shameful return thou hast devised.
tgt_text.2686: No long time, I trow, shalt thou escape Æetes’ fearful wrath;
tgt_text.2687: for soon will he go even to the homes in the land of Hellas, to take vengeance for the murder of his son;
tgt_text.2688: seeing that thou hast wrought a terrible deed.
tgt_text.2689: But, for­ asmuch as thou art my suppliant and of my race, I will devise no further evil against thee at thy coming hither;
tgt_text.2690: but get thee from my house in company with this stranger, this fellow whom thou hast taken unbeknown to thy father;
tgt_text.2691: entreat me not, sitting at my hearth, for I will not consent to thy counsels and thy shameful flight.
tgt_text.2693: and grievous sorrow laid hold upon Medea, and she wrapt her robe about her eyes and wept;
tgt_text.2694: till the hero took her by the hand and led her forth to the door of the hall, quivering with terror;
tgt_text.2695: so they left the house of Circe.
tgt_text.2696: But they escaped not the knowledge of the wife of Zeus, the son of Cronos;
tgt_text.2697: but Iris told her, when she marked them going from the hall.
tgt_text.2698: For Hera bade her watch them closely, until they came unto the ship, and again she spake and hailed her, " Dear Iris, now, if ever thou hast accom­ plished my bidding, come, speed thee on swift wings and bid Thetis arise from out the deep, and come hither to me.
tgt_text.2699: For need of her aid is come upon me ;
tgt_text.2700: and next get thee to the cliffs, where the brazen anvils of Hephæstus clang to the blows of his heavy hammers, and bid him lull his fiery blasts to rest, until Argo has sailed by those cliffs.
tgt_text.2701: Then go to Æolus, Æolus who rules the wind, children of the upper air, and tell him this my mind, that he make all wind to cease under heaven, and suffer no breeze to roughen the sea;
tgt_text.2702: only let a favouring west-wind blow, that the heroes may come to the Phæacian isle of Alcinous.
tgt_text.2704: and forthwith Iris darted from Olympus, cleaving her way, with her light wings outspread.
tgt_text.2705: And she plunged into the Ægean sea, just where the home of Nereus is.
tgt_text.2706: And she came to Thetis first, and told her tale as Hera bade, and roused her to go to her.
tgt_text.2708: and quickly stayed him from his iron hammers, and his sooty bellows ceased from their blast.
tgt_text.2709: Lastly came she to Æolus, famous son of Hippotas.
tgt_text.2710: And even while she was telling him her message, and resting her swift knees from her course, did Thetis leave Nereus and her sisters and go from the sea to Olympus, unto the goddess Hera, who made her sit beside her, and declared her speech ;
tgt_text.2712: Hearken now, lady Thetis, to that which I fain would tell thee.
tgt_text.2713: Thou knowest how dear to my heart is the hero son of Æson, and those others that do help him in his toil;
tgt_text.2714: for 'twas I alone, that saved them in their passage through the wandering rocks, where erst dire tempests roared and the billows boiled round the rugged rocks.
tgt_text.2715: But now awaits them a journey past the mighty rock of Scylla, and Charybdis, horribly belching.
tgt_text.2718: 'twas I that with mine own hands tended and caressed thee from thine infancy above all others, who dwell within the sea, because thou wouldst not yield to the importunities of Zeus.
tgt_text.2719: For he is ever bent on such deeds, to lie with women, be they mortal or immortal.
tgt_text.2720: But thou, from reverence of me and from fear, didst avoid him;
tgt_text.2721: wherefore he then did swear a mighty oath, that thou shouldst never be called the wife of an immortal god.
tgt_text.2722: Yet did he lie in wait for thee an unwilling mate, and would not give thee up, until aged Themis told him all, how that of a surety it was ordained that thou shouldst bear a son better than his father;
tgt_text.2723: wherefore he gave thee up, for all his strong desire, in fear that another should be his rival and rule the deathless gods, yea, and for ever wrest away his power.
tgt_text.2724: But I gave thee the best1 of mortal men to be thy husband, that thou mightest find the joys of wedlock and bear children ;
tgt_text.2725: and to thy marriage-feast I bade the gods, one and all, and with mine own hand raised the wedding torch,2 to repay that thy generous respect.
tgt_text.2726: But come now, I will tell thee a tale that lieth not;
tgt_text.2727: when so thy son cometh to the Elysian plain, he, I mean, whom water-nymphs now do tend in the home of the Centaur Chiron, though he longeth for thy milk;
tgt_text.2728: needs must3 he be the husband of Medea, daughter of Æetes ;
tgt_text.2729: do thou, then, as a mother, help thy future daughter, and Peleus as well.
tgt_text.2730: Why is thy wrath so firmly rooted ?
tgt_text.2732: for even to gods will blindness come.
tgt_text.2733: Verily I do think that at my bidding Hephæstus will cease to make his furious fire burn, and Æolus, son of Hippotas, will check the winds' swift flight, all save the steady west, until they come to the havens of the Phaeacians;
tgt_text.2734: so do thou devise for them a painless return.
tgt_text.2735: My only fear is for thy rocks and mountainous billows, which, with the aid of thy other sisters, thou canst turn aside.
tgt_text.2737: leave them not to drift helplessly into Charybdis, lest with one gulp she take them all down, nor let them come to Scylla's foul lair, murderous Scylla of Ausonia, whom Hecate that roameth by night, bare to Phorcus, whom men call ‘the Mighty One,' lest haply she dart upon them with her fearful jaws and slay the chosen heroes.
tgt_text.2738: But keep thou the ship just in the course where there shall be a hair-breadth escape from destruction.
tgt_text.2742: If, of a. truth, the furious raging fire and the stormy winds shall cease, verily I too will with confidence promise to save the ship from the wave's attack too, while the west wind is piping.
tgt_text.2743: But'tis time to set out upon my long weary way,.
tgt_text.2744: till I shall come unto my sisters, who shall help me, and to the place where the ship's cables are fastened, that at dawn they may bethink them of winning their return.
tgt_text.2745: "Therewith she shot down from the sky and plunged amid the eddies of the deep blue sea, and she called other Nereids, her own sisters, to her aid, and they heard her voice and came together.
tgt_text.2746: Then Thetis rehearsed the bid­ ding of Hera, and sent them all at once to the Ausonian sea.
tgt_text.2747: But herself, swifter than the twinkling of an eye, or the rays of the sun, when he riseth high above the horizon, sped quickly on her way through the water, till she reached the Ææan cliff of the Tyrsenian mainland.
tgt_text.2748: There she found the heroes by the ship, taking their pastime with quoits and archery, and she drew near and took Peleus, son of Æacus, by the hand, for he was her husband, but no man might see her at all;
tgt_text.2749: only to his eye did she appear, and thus spake she:
tgt_text.2750: " Abide no longer now sitting on the Tyrsenian strand, but at dawn loose the hawsers of the swift ship, in obedience to Hera, your champion.
tgt_text.2751: For at her command my Nereid maids are met, to send your ship in safety, and with all speed through the rocks which are called ‘the Wanderers.'
tgt_text.2752: For that is your proper route.
tgt_text.2753: But do thou point me out to no man, what time thou seest me present with these;
tgt_text.2754: lay that to heart, lest thou anger me in more downright earnest than ever thou hast afore.
tgt_text.2755: "Therewith she plunged unseen into the depths of the sea, and sore grief smote Peleus, for he had never seen her come, since first she left her bridal chamber in anger, when noble Achilles was yet a babe.
tgt_text.2756: For the goddess ever used to wrap about his mortal body fiery flame through the night, and by day she would anoint his tender skin with am­ brosia,.
tgt_text.2757: that he might become immortal, and that she might ward off hateful old age from his body.
tgt_text.2758: But Peleus saw his dear son gasping in the flame, and he sprang from his bed with a cry of horror at the sight, fond fool!
